 1. CURRENT SITUATION AND BACKGROUND 1.1 Civil war and unrest have plagued Sierra Leone for more than nine years. Since 1991, successive governments have been unable to completely defeat the rebel forces of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), and a coup d'etat led by disgruntled junior anny officers in May 1997 ousted the government of Ahmad Tejan Kabbah after only 14 months in office. Though the President was reinstated to power in February 1998 by the regional military forces of the Economic Community of West African States' Monitoring Group (ECOMOG), the security situation deteriorated toward the end of the same year culminatg in a well-coordinated attack on Freetown by RUF and former Sierra Leonean army forces in January 1999. While the attack on Freetown was countered by ECOMOG forces, property damage and loss of life were high particularly in the eastem part of the city, the large areas of the northern and eastern provinces of the country fell under the control of rebels and former Sierra Leone army forces. In response, diplomatic missions and nearly all international agencies pulled out of the country. Subsequent to the atack, ECOMOG has slowly regained control over some of the territory that it had lost to the rebels and a military stalemate was established. 1.2 The attack on Freetown was significant for two main reasons. First, it demonstrated that the forces of the RUF and the former Sierra Leonean Army (SLA) that had led the military coup in 1997 were Lrger in number and better organized and equipped than previously believed. Second, the subsequent stalemate reaffirmed that a strictly military solution to the problem would be impossible. These two facts hasten the international community and the leadership of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) to advocate more forcefully to the Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL) for a negotiated settlement to the conflict. With the active support of the ECOWAS Chairman and the United Nations Special Envoy to the Secretary General, the Government entered into political discussions with representatives of the RUF in May following a cease-fire agreement. By June a peace agreement had been drafted and the RUF political leadership had discussed the main elements of the agreement with their field commanders. On July 7, 1999, the President of Sierra Leone, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, and the political leader of the RUF, Foday Sankoy, signed the peace agreement ending the armed conflict that had plagued Sierra Leone for almost a decade. 1.3 Sierra Leone and its development partners are now in the process of consolidating this peace agreement, operationalizing a national disarmament, demobilization and reintegration program, extending humanitarian relief activities and renewing national reconstruction efforts. The return to Sierra Leone in early October of Foday Sankoy and Johnny Paul Koroma (leader of the military junta) to take up responsibilities with the current government and to initiate the political process which will allow the RUF and the AFRC to stand for office in the upcoming presidential elections is a promising sign that the peace will hold. The international community is moving quickly to help the govermnent consolidate its current position and to extend financial assistance to face the challenges of the post-conflict recovery programs.
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Conumunity Reintegration and Rehabilitation County: Sierra Leone Page 5 of87 Background and Summary of the Conflict 1.4 The root causes of the civil war can be traced to the systematic long-term neglect of the rural areas of the country and the exclusion of certain groups from political decision-making under previous governments. Local government was deliberately weakened and lacked transparency, the judicial system had lost credibility, infiastructure had decayed and the provision of social services had deteriorated consistently over a period of twenty-five years. 1.5 The immediate causes of the war can be linked to the civil war in neighboring Liberia and the subsequent establishment and militarization of the Revolutionary United Front of Sierra Leone. The Government of Sierra Leone supported the ECOMOG peacekeeping operation in Liberia, which clashed with Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) in 1990. In retaliation, the NPFL provided military assistance to a small movement of disaffected Sierra Leonean exiles known as the Revolutionary United Front. The civil war in Sierra Leone began on 23 March 1991, when the RUF, under the leadership of former Corporal Foday Sankoh, initiated a guerrilla war in the east of the country. The stated objective of the RUF was to oust the All People's Congress government of President J.S. Momoh. The Sierra Leone armed forces were caught by surprise and were ill-equipped to confront the RUF threat. The conflict soon spread to the southern and central regions of the country. 1.6 The war intensified in late 1994, when the RUF significantly expanded the scale and scope of its military activities and threatened Freetown. As a result of this escalation of hostilities and the associated breakdown of civil authority in large areas of the country, an estimated 1.5 million civilians from war-affeted areas fled to towns and cities in search of refuge. Important mining operations such as Sierra Rutile, the Sieromco bauxite mine and key diamond fields, were overtaken by the RUF twice in early 1995. This escalation reduced Sierra Leone's official gross foreign exchange earnings by 500/o, disrupted agricultural production and curtailed the activities of development agencies and the private sector. 1.7 From mid-1995 onwards, the RUF suffered a series of military defeats as a result of the introduction by GOSL of Executive Outcomes1 and the gradual strengthening of the camajoh (civil defense forces (CDF)) movement. With this series of military defeats and following the multi-party elections in early 1996, the RUF agreed to a cease-fire and entered into direct negotiations with the new Govermment of Ahmad Tejan Kabbah in March 1996. After several months of negotiations and further kamajoh military pressure, the discussions culminated in the signing of the Abidjan Peace Accord on November 30, 1996. 1.8 The Abidjan Accord, however, was not to be fully implemented. While certain elements of the Accord were put in place - such as the establishment of a bi-partisan Commission for the Consolidation of Peace - other aspects such as the formulation of a demobilization plan and the deployment of peacekeeping forces were not. Escalaing hostilities between the armed forces, the kamajors/CDF, and RUF, and deteriorating security in the provinces, were harbingers of the coup in May 1997. 1.9 The AFRC coup was different from previous transitions in power in Sierra Leone in several ways. First, not only was the executive branch overthrown, but the legislative process and judicial system were also significantly debilitated or, for the most part, destroyed. Second, nascent recovery efforts of the 14-month old Government were all but suspended with the closing I A private security advisory group.
 Technical Annex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Country: Sierra Leone Page 6 of 87 of most international donor and development operations, withdrawal of international staff, and suspension of development aid. Finally, the level of random violence against civilian populations and both public and private property had significant negative impact on the social fabric of the countly and on business and investor confidence. 1.10 Restoration of the legitimate Government by ECOMOG in February 1998 brought once more hope to resolve the conflict. The long process of rebuilding the country could again be initiated. Important advances were made subsequently, most notably the design of a comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration program. While the program received wide international support and funding commitments, the security situation in the country deteriorated. This culminated in the brutal January 1999 attack on Freetown. Most international aid efforts to Sierra Leone were subsequently suspended. It is only with the signing of the Lom6 Peace Agreement, which incorporates guarantees of free access for humanitarian agencies to rebel-held areas, that humanitarian relief -, development - and donor organizations are again looking to expand operations outside the relative safety of Westem Area. The Lome Peace Agreement 1.11 The Lome Peace Agreement, was signed on July 7, 1999, by President Tejan Kabbah and Foday Sankoh of the RUF, and witnessed by the Chairman of ECOWAS, the UN Special Envoy to the Secretary General, and representatives of key regional governments. This Peace Agreement established the foundation for a lasting peace, return of security and initiation of reconstruction and development for Sierra Leone. Specifically, the Peace Agreement: (i) reiterates the earlier signed cease-fire agreement and establishes appropriate bodies to monitor its implementation; (ii) facilitates the transformation of the RUF into a political party and allows for the RUF and AFRC personnel to hold public office; (iii) enables the RUF to join a Government of National Unity through the appointment of Foday Sankoy as chairman of a newly formed Commission for the Management of Strategic Resources, National Reconstruction and Development, and providing the RUF with four minister and four deputy minister positions; (iv) establishes a Commission for the Consolidation of Peace that will oversee the implementation of all structures and efforts aimed at the promotion of national reconciliation and the consolidation of peace either in existence or provided for under the Peace Agreement; and (v) establishes a Council of Elders and Religious Leaders to serve as arbitrators of the Agreement in the event of conflicting interpretations by the parties. The full text of the Peace Agreement is presented in Attachment 1 to this document. 1.12 While this is not the first agreement of its kind reached between rebel forces and the GOSL, it is hoped that the level of international support for the accord (and in particular the participation of the regional governments of Liberia2 and Guinea, as well as Nigeria that supplies the majority of soldiers to the ECOMOG force) will prove critical in seeing this accord implemented. The design and preliminary implementation of a comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration progrm, which was lacking in previous peace efforts, is also seen as essential to the long-term success of the accord. In addition, the recent return to Sierra Leone of both Foday Sankoh and Johnny Paul Koroma to assume their respective responsibilities as defined in the Peace Agreement is a promising sign that the political will of these two parties is 2 It is noteworthy that President Taylor of Liberia, who it has long been rumored was supporting the RUF and AFRC against the GOSL, recently brokered the agreement between Foday Sankoy and Johnny Paul Koroma to return to Sierra Leone as called for in the Peace Agreement

Finally, the active participation of both RUF and AFRC representatives in the process of operationalizing the disarmament and demobilization activities lends further hope that the accord will be fully implemented. Overall Economic and Social Impact of the War and Post-Coup Conflict 1.13 Eight years of war and coup-related unrest have devastated the national economy and led to large scale social disruption. Substantive damage has been caused to the agriculture and mining sectors, thereby greatly reducing rural food security and revenue earning capacity of the country. A large percentage of public infrastructure has been destroyed, or has deteriorated due to lack of maintenance. The loss of control over resources and diminished government revenues drastically reduced foreign exchange receipts and fiscal revenues. The civil war has caused a decline in export earnings from mineral resources, a decline in agricultural productivity and increased imports of essential food items, such as rice and military equipment. 1.14 In spite of the civil unrest that plagued the country during the 1990's, the Government had implemented a successful series of stabilization and structural reform policies that had yielded significant results up until the time of the coup in May, 1997. From 1990/91 to 1996, annual inflaion was reduced from over 100 percent to around 6 percent, and the budget deficit was reduced from 12 percent of GDP to 6.8 percent in the period from 1989/90 to 1996. These gains were achieved while at the same time protecting social sector spending despite budgetary pressures related to the war. However, nine months of junta rule in 1997, and predominantly unstable economic and political conditions during 1998 and early 1999 have reversed most of ese advances. Real GDP was estimated to have contracted by over 20 percent in 1997, and the overail budget deficit stood at 11.4 percent of GDP in 1998. It is estimated that real output declined by approximately 9 percent during the first half of 1999. Nonetheless, the economic siuation during the second half of 1999 is expected to improve with the political stabilization resulting from the implementation of the July Peace Agreement. Government revenue is projected to increase, and while budget outlays are also expected to increase in relation to emergency relief and rehabilitation expenditures, the primary budget deficit for the year as a whole is projected to be 7.8 percent of GDP. Nonetheless, given the expected resumption of budgetary and other assistance in the last quarter of the year, the reliance on bank financing to cover the budget deficit is expected to significantly decline, thereby reducing inflationary pressure and stemming the fia in gross external reserves. An IMF mission, in October 1999, will establish with Government the indicative reserve targets for end-December 1999, as part of their proposed emergency post-conflict assistance policy program for Sierra Leone. 1.15 The social costs of the conflict have been equally high. Delivery of basic social services has been dramatically curtailed in areas outside of the capital. Since 1991, more thn twenty-five thousand lives have been lost as a direct result of the conflict. The war and related insecurity have also caused the internal displacement of an estimated 1.2 million people (out of a total population of 4.7 million), and most of the rural displaced fled to urban environments characterized by inadequate housing and poor sanitary conditions. The population of Greater Freetown alone increased from 731,000 in 1989 to more than 1.5 million by late 1995, thus further straining already overburdened social services. Many of the displaced have been housed by extended families, thus also stretching traditional coping mechanisms to their limits. As of August 1999, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) reports that there are still 150,000 registered internally displaced persons (IDPs). However OCHA estimates that as many as 1 million people are at risk due to insecurity and the inability of humanitarian agencies to access large parts of the northern and eastern regions of the
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Counhy: &erra Leone Page 8 of 87 county. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimates that more than 500,000 people have fled Sierra Leone for neighboring countries since 1991, and that at present almost the same number remain in neighboring countries. 1.16 The war and subsequent tunmoil have exacerbated already high levels of poverty in Sierra Leone. Prior to 1991 it is estimated that about 80 percent of the population lived on less than one dollar per day. Since then, the situation has deteriorated with the widespread destruction of public infrasucture, massive population displacements, and the withdrawal of foreign investment. The civil war and post-coup period have also been characterized by economic rent- seeking. Looting for food, cash crops and other material goods became a means of survival and often a source of profitable business for elements within both the RUF and the AFRSL. Moreover, control over the illicit diamond mining and trade in the areas bordering Liberia became a way for the RUF to finance the procurement of arms and other supplies. These factors contributed significantly to the prolongation of the war. 1.17 The conflict has also contributed to the weakening of traditional authority structures at the chiefdom level, and the reduction of trust at the community and family levels, as leaders and elders have been killed or displaced, women have been sexually abused and children have been abducted. Systematic attacks on authority figures (both human and symbolic- as in desecration of secret society "bushes") were a feature of RUF stategy. The remnants of the AFRC junta have also tried to undermine the existing authority structures in the towns and villages that they have attacked since being ousted by ECOMOG. Nonetheless, these social structures too have shown remarkable resilience. Many chiefs were sent out of harm's way by their subjects in order to protect their authority; the displaced persons camps have typically been organized in accordance with chiefdom structures; and the command, control and recruitmnent mechanisms for the kamajoh/CDF movement are closely linked to the chiefdom governance system. Civil society reaction to and condemnation of the May coup was rapid, the call for a return of the democratically elected government was loud, and, ironically, the nine-month period of AFRC rule served to strengthen many local level institutions that were left to fend for themselves in the absence of any central-level support or control. Since the return of the Kabbah government, civil society representatives have been both active and vocal in calling for a peaceful settlement of the 9-year conflict. 1.18 The civil war and the coup are clearly both symptoms and causes of the weakness of the Sierra Leonean state. The long-term decline of state services, a governance system characterized by corruption, and the politics of regional exclusion were key causes of the civil war. The large scale destruction of infrastructure, economic resources and social displacement in the course of the conflicts have further weakened the governance capacity of the state. The recovery and reintegration process must address the underlying socio-economic causes of the war for Sierra Leone to resume a path of peaceful and democratic social and economic development. Security 1.19 Security in Sierra Leone has improved significantly since the low point in January 1999 when AFRC and RUF forces attacked Freetown. A cease-fire agreement signed in May of this year has held, GOSL and RUF representatives took part in detailed technical discussions in Togo during May and June, and on July 7, 1999, a Peace Agreement was signed between the GOSL and the RUF. Since then, RUF and AFRC leadership (Sankoy and Koroma) have retumed to Freetown and are traveling around the country briefing their respective forces on the peace agreement, disamament and demobilization; RUF and AFRC representatives have begun
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Counbty: Slerra Leone Page 9 of 87 participating at operational levels in the implementation of the disarmament and demobilization efforts; and while some tensions remain, especially in relation to AFRC representation in the Peace Agreement, these have been defused through negotiations rather than violence. Access to the capitals of the Southern and Eastern provinces has been restored and while rebel troops still control large portions of the north and east of the country, they have established procedures and mechanisms to allow humanitarian agencies access to these areas and the at-risk populations there. The UN has improved the security rating for Western Area and Southem Province to a level 3 and the US Embassy has reopened at the end of September, 1999. It is expected that with the rapid implementation of the Government's comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration (DDR) program the security situation in the North and East of the country will improve rapidly. Current Situation 1.20 Sierra Leone reached a low point in its nine year rebel war, when RUF and AFRC forces mounted a well-coordinated attack on Freetown that drove the ECOMOG forces responsible for maintaining security in the country out of two-hirds of the city. A week-long battle ensued in the central and eastem parts of the city hat resulted in an estimated 5,000 deaths, as yet uncalculated destruction of property, and the displacement of more than 50,000 citizens from the eastern end and outskirts of the city. ECOMOG forces were eventually able to regain control of the city, the Western Area, and some territory lost to the advancing forces in December and January. A military stalemate was achieved with the Western and Southern areas of the country controlled by ECOMOG and CDF personnel, while large portions of the East and North of the country were held by rebels. The result of this siuation was a clearer realization on the part of the Government and the international community that had been supporung Tejan Kabbah that a negotiated settlement with the rebel forces was the only practical option. This led to detailed technical discussions between the GOSL and RUF leadership, which allowed the RUF leadership (Foday Sankoh) to meet with RUF field commders. At the same time, a 3-day "National Consulation on the Peace Process" exercise was undertaken by civil society representatives aimed at strengtening the Government's mandate in the peace negotiations. Ultimately, in this context, and with the encouragement and support of the ECOWAS Chairman and the UN Special Envoy to the Secretary General, the Government and the RUF signed a Peace Agreement in Lom6 on July 7, 1999. 1.21 The signing of the Peace Agreement has led to almost immediate action on the part of Government and its major development partners to begin addressing the humanitarian crises that is looming in large areas of the country (most notably the north and east); the need to disarm, demobilize and reintegrate a now estimated 45,000 combatants from the forces of the RUF, AFRC, AFSL and the CDF; and to restart interrupted efforts at rebuilding the lives and communities that have been adversely affected by the past nine years of conflict. The Government has helped coordinate the humanitarian efforts of the NGOs, UN agencies and line ministries, and has revised and updated the National Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration Program based on the changing circumstances post-January 1999. A multi-donor mission carried out in September 1999 reviewed and reiterated its support of the priorities previously identified by Government, including: security, demobilization and reintegration of ex- combatants, implementation of the national reconstruction, rehabilitation and resettlement program, governance and rule of law, economic management, decentralization and capacity building. The International Contact Group (ICG) for Sierra Leone is monitoring the implementation of Government's respective recovery efforts and is seeking to assist the Govermment to mobilize resources for these priority areas. In terms of security, the Economic
 TechnicalAnnex Project Titk: Community Reintegration andRehabilitation Countfy: Sierra Leone Page 10 of 87 Community of West African States has agreed to maintain the presence of the 12,000 person- strong ECOMOG force to maintain security until a new Sierra Leonean army can be recruited and trained, and the United Nations has approved a team of 210 military observers (UNOMSIL) to monitor the disariament and demobilization process and to take receipt of surrendered weapons. In October 1999, the UN Security Council approved a 6,000 person strong Peace Keeping force for Sierra Leone. 1.22 The President formally established two government institutions with responsibility for overseeing the short-term reintegration and rehabilitation efforts of the country: the National Committee for Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR), and the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation (NCRRR). The overall managers of each institution (respectively, the Executive Secretary and the Commissioner) have been appointed and core technical staffed recruited and hired. The Government has also begun implementing concrete efforts to resume its role as coordinator and facilitator of the overall recovery and reconstruction efforts of government ministries, NGOs, and community groups. The NCRRR structure and staffing requirements have been reviewed and revised in careful consultation with donors, a plan of action and three-year budget have been developed and are being considered by NCRRR's major partners, and the coordination mechanisms at central and regional levels have been reestablished and are funcdoning with a high degree of efficiency. 1.23 In 1998, the GOSL also developed a comprehensive program framework for the disaLmament demobilization and reintegration (DDR) of all ex-combatants (including AFRSL, RUF, and CDF personnel). The proposed strategies of the DDR Program were discussed at the special UN conference held in July, 1998, that was well-attended and resulted in renewed international commitment to Sierra Leone and its programs of national recovery, as well as support to ECOMOG. The UK Department for Intemational Development (DFID) provided technical and financial assistance to facilitate the implementation of phase I of the program that had targeted approximately 7,000 ex-combatants. However, the breakdown in security in late 1998 that culminated in the January 6, 1999, attack on Freetown interrupted activities under the DDR program, as well as humanitarian and nascent reconstruction efforts in much of the country. 1.24 Subsequently to the January 6t attack on Freetown, the GOSL undertook to review the status of the DDR Program jointly with key partners including ECOMOG, UNOMSIL, UNICEF, DFID, EU, World Bank and other civil society stakeholders. This review was initiated in the context of promising signs that a conducive political environment had developed that would lead to a political settlement of the conflict. Following the signing of the Lome Peace Agreement, the program has been restarted with the opening of the demobilization camp in Lungi, continuation of training activities, and the identification of possible short-term public works employment opportunities for the ex-combatants. The DDR program is currently moving ahead quickly with the establishment of necessary reception centers and demobilization camps in different areas of the country. 1.25 The level of commitment and ownership on the part of the Government for these initiatives, the substantive progress made in initiating key program activities, and the wide-spread international donor community support for the Government's efforts encourages hope for the success of the overall recovery efforts of Sierra Leone and its partners.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE AND STRATEGY Government Strategy 2.1 In light of a cease-fire brokered with the RUF in early 1996, the Govermnent of Sierra Leone carried out an extensive needs assessment of war-affected areas as the basis for formulating a national plan for the resetdement, rehabilitation, and reconstruction of the country. The plan, referred to as the National Resettlement, Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Program (NRRRP), was presented to the donor community at a UNDP Roundtable Conference in September 1996. At the core of the NRRRP was an initial Quick Action Program (QUAP) that focused on 17 different sectors or program areas considered crucial for the social and economic recovery and revitalization of the country. The QUAP specifically targeted short-term priority areas of post-war reconstruction, focusing on resettlement of displaced persons, demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants, re-establishment of basic social services, and reconstruction of economic infrastructure particularly related to agricultural production. The signing of the first Peace Agreement between the Government and the RUF in November 1996 gave hope to national and international efforts to begin the recovery process in earnest. Commitments made in September began to become project agreements between donor countries, the GOSL, and various implementing partners on the ground. The Roundtable Conference yielded pledges of approximately US$230 million, and formal commitments were estimated at 50% of this total by November, 1996. 2.2 During the same period, the Government elaborated a Poverty Reduction Strategy that was anchored on the principle of growth with equity, and developed a Good Governance Strategy that dealt with decentralization of admstration, civil service refonn, strengthening of civil society, and promotion of transparency and accountability in the public service. These strategy documents were presented to a Consultative Group of donors in March, 1997, resulting in pledges of more than US$600 million. The coup of May 1997, however, effectively put the NRRRP, the QUAP, as well as these other program activities, on hold. 2.3 While President Tejan Kabbah's Government was in exile, and immediately following the reinstatement of democratic rule in March 1998, the Government considered its options and the priority actions it would take to ensure rapid recovery of the country upon its return to power. Two documents were prepared that highlighted the GOSL's vision for national recovery, namely: Restoration to Democratic Civilian Rule in Sierra Leone; a 90 Day Programme (November 1997), and Post-conflict Recovery Programme; Preparedfor Consultations with Donors - March 1998. The conclusion of the second document is that the original NRRRP and QUAP priorities and funding esinates remain valid and that these program documents should continue to guide discussions with the Government's development partners and the donor community in general. The original and revised GOSL estimates of costs for the QUAP are shown in Table 2-1. 2.4 Innmediately upon returning to power, the Government undertook to develop a comprehensive program of disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants - a specific and concerted strategy notably absent from the Government's pre-coup recovery program. The Program, described in the National Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration Program (NDDRP) document of July 1998 (amended in April 1999), will target
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitahon County: Sierra Leone Page 12 of 87 approximately 45,000 former combatants of the AFSL, AFRC, the RUF, and the CDF in three phases over a three-year period. The program has been developed with the assistance of several donors including DFID, UNDP, World Bank, and UNOMSIL, and has benefited from close Government consultations with ECOMOG. The Government has shown the highest level of political commitment, mobilized broad support from stakeholders and the international community, and moved quickly to establish the implementation strategies and structures required for the program. The NDDRP, estimated to cost approximately US$33.5 million3, was presented to and received the wide support of the international community at a special conference called by the UN Secretary General in July, 1998. An initial phase to demobilize 3,000 former anny personnel held by ECOMOG was initiated in late 1998 and is now being completed after a six- month hiatus resuling from the attack on Freetown. Additional support for the NDDRP is being consolidated through the International Consultative Group that was formed as a result of the July 1998, UN Conference. Program Framework and Resource Requirements 2.6 In view of the diverse and interrelated natre of the problems engendered by the conflict, as well as the country's long-term socio-economic decline, GOSL recognizes the need for a comprehensive strategic framework for guiding the reconstruction and recovery processes. Moreover, since the country is still in transition from war to peace, the program is anchored within the context of a continuum from relief to development. Within this framework, the short- run emergency relief, resettlement, rehabilitation, and reintegration measures are intended to lay the foundation for resumption of normal development activities. To ensure a successful transition to the development phase, it is recognized that measures would have to be put in place for the demobilization of ex-combatants and their reinsertion into civil society, as well as for an orderly rturn and reintegration of the intemally displaced and refugees. 2.7 With the considerable loss of production capacity in most parts of the country and the deterioration and/or destruction of much of the basic physical and socio-economic infrastructure, it is essential that quick rehabilitation measures be put in place immediately after the resettlement of the displaced people. This will contribute to the restoration of an appropriate socio-economic environment necessary for normal development processes over the medium-term. Analysis of Commitments to the NRRRP and NDDRP 2.8 Before assessing the commitments, it is important to recapitulate two important expectations about program financing related to the extent of local participation, and the nature of -exnal assistance. First, from the outset, it was estimated that the local contribution to the progran would be in the order of 10-15%. This would comprise contributions by Government, local communities, the private sector and external sources. Government's contribution would be in the form of budgetary allocations to cover mainly the local cost of both development and recurrent expenditures. The contribution of local communities is expected to be principally in kind, through the provision of local materials and labor for community programs and projects. Regarding the private sector, the expectation is that it would progressively promote some of the planned activities, from transportation of relief goods to reconstruction and developmental activities. Second, with respect to international support, it is expected that funding would come pardy from re-allocations of already committed funds, the utilization of which had been constrained by the escalaton of the war. Government recognizes that redirecting existing loans and grants would have to be negotiated in detail with individual donors and international financial institutions. 2.9 The most significant commitments to the post-war recovery programs have been made by the following international organizations: UNDP and other UN agencies, World Bank, European Union, African Development Bank/Fund, and by the Governments of the UK, US, Germany, Japan, Saudi Arabia, and others. PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION 3.1 The Government of Sierra Leone has prepared and presented to the international community two programs for economic and social renewal in response to eight years of armed conflict and more than two decades of misrule, neglect of social infrastructure, and misuse of economic assets. These programs are outlined in the National Resettlement, Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Program (NRRRP) and the Nahtonal Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration Program (NDDRP) documents. Both of these program documents have been widely distributed to and received support from the international donor community and Sierra Leone's development partners, first at the UNDP Roundtable Conference held in Geneva in September, 1996, and more recently at the special UN conference sponsored by the Secretary General in New York in July 1998. 3.2 Upon being reinstated to power in March, 1998, President Kabbah formally established the two institutions that would oversee the implementation of the two national programs outlined in these documents. These institutions, the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation (NCRRR) and the National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR), have limited and time-bound mandates, are staffed by local consultants, and will operate outside of standard civil service procedures to help maintain their independence and improve their efficiency. NCRRR will coordinate and monitor implementation of the NRRRP, while NCDDR will have responsibility for overseeing the NDDRP. National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation 3.3 In light of the integrated and multi-sectoral needs of reconstruction and recovery, both Government and key donors have recognized the need for a sectorally integrated mechanism to oversee the NRRRP. NCRRR has been created to fulfill this role in the same way that the former Ministry of National Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation was. Unlike its predecessor, however, NCRRR does not have a civil service administrative branch. Also, in line with donor and development partner recommendations, the Commission has rationalized its structure to better reflect its coordination and monitoring mandate, and has strengthened the focus on decentralized sub-project appraisal. The organiional structre of NCRRR is shown in Figure 3-1 on the following page. 3.4 NCRRR will facilitate dialogue between and coordinate the programs and activities of NGOs, line ministries, donor agencies and other implementing partners active in the emergency recovery program, and monitor and report on all recovery activities undertaken in the country. NCRRR will also oversee the implementation of the Emergency Recovery Support Fund (ERSF), a demand driven community-based social fund designed to facilitate the social and economic recovery of communities and the restoration of basic social and economic services. The ERSF targets internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and ex-combatants. However, in keeping with its inter-sectoral and coordination role, the Commission will not directly implement recovery activities financed by the ERSF; this responsibility will rest with its partner organizations, including NGOs, line ministries, public authorities and community based organizations.

COORDINATION MECHANISMS IN PLACE 4.1 Overall aid management and coordination in Sierra Leone continues to be weak, although the Government is making efforts to limit the entry channels for resources and streamline the control system. The Department of Development (under the Ministry of Finance, Development and Economic Planning) is charged with the responsibility of coordinating, managing and monitoring development assistance, of which the NRRRP and NDDRP will be mrajor components in the near term. However, specific responsibility for the coordination of activities related to the recovery efforts is the responsibility of NCRRR, while those related to demobilization and reintegration will fall to NCDDR. Still, donor agencies and international NGOs continue to deal directly with the respective line ministries, or in some cases regional authorities, with which they have long-standing relations and a tradition of cooperation. While information on these respective funding decisions and activities is, for the most part, transmitted to one or more GOSL office, the Government's capacity to collect and consolidate this information, or to monitor the work of these partners, is inadequate. 4.2 Nonetheless, Government's recent efforts to better coordinate the emergency relief and initial recovery phase have been more successful due in large part to the assistance provided by the Hmanitarian Affairs Coordinating Unit (HACU) of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN-OCHA). Given the complex nature of the situation, and the frequent need to respond quickly to an emerging crises in a multi-sectoral fashion, GOSL has taken a number of steps to strengthen coordination. While NCRRR has taken a lead role in this area, other organizations are involved in the coordination of the National Programs as well. These organizations and their inter-linkages are described below. National Level 4.3 Inter-Msrnteial Committee. This Ministerial-level Program Steering Committee was established to facilitate the smooth operations of all aspects of the NRRR Program. This Committee is chaired by the Commissioner of NCRRR, and is composed of the Ministers of Finance, Development and Economic Planning; Agnculture, Forestry and Environment; Local Govermuent, Land and Housing; Education; Health and Sanitation; and Social Welfire, Gender and Children's Affairs. The Steering Committee meets regularly to deal with policy issues and to address problems and constraints to NRRRP implementation, and will provide guidance to NCRRR. 4.4 National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration. NCDDR is the policy making body for the DDR Program chaired by the President and is comprised of the: National Security Advisor, ECOMOG Task Force Commander, Deputy Minister of Defense, Minister of Internal Affirs and Local Administration, NCRRR Commissioner, Minister of Finance, Development and Economic Planning, Minister of Informaution, the Special Envoy of the UN Secretary General, a representative of the lead donor agency (the British High Commissioner), and the Executive Secretary of the NCDDR as Committee secretary. NCDDR formulates national strategies for, and coordinates all governmental activities that support, the DDR Program; the Executive Secretariat (ES) will be responsible for carrying out the policy and implementing, on a day-to-day basis, the responsibilities of the Government under the DDR Program.

OBJECTIVES, RATIONALE AND STRATEGY FOR BANK ASSISTANCE Rationale for Bank Involvement 5.1 The GOSL clearly recognizes that demobilization and the subsequent social and economic reintegration of ex-combatants, IDPs, and refugees are crucial for achieving lasting peace, stability and economic growth. The Government has explicitly outlined its strategies for addressing these priorities in two program documents previously noted (i.e., the National Resettlement, Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Program (NRRRP) and the National Disarmament, Demobilizanon and Reintegration Program (NDDRP)). The first progran is based on an extensive needs assessment of war-affected areas carried out by the GOSL in mid- 1996, which was submitted to the international community at a UNDP Round Table Conference in September 1996 in Geneva. Subsequent to the restoration of democratic rule in March 1998, the GOSL reiterated the priorities outlined in this first document and the donor community indicated their agreement with these priorities in the Joint Governent/Donor Communiqu6 issued in May, 1998. The second document, prepared after the return of the Kabbah Government, was presented to the international community at a special meeting called by the UN Secretary General in July 1998. 5.2 Both documents have been well received by donor agencies and development partners active in Sierra Leone, and these organizations have moved quickly to support the program strtegies outlined therein. Specifically: the United States, the European Union, UN agencies and non-governmental organizations are assisting with emergency relief food security, and emergency health services; DFID, UNOMSIL, and the Office of the Special Envoy on the UN Secretary General are helping to support the demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants; and UNDP, the African Development Bank, and the Islamic Development Bank are helping to strengthen the institutional capacity of the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation. 5.3 The commitment of the GOSL and the international community to the recovery process presents a unique "window of opportunity" to revitalize Sierra Leone's economic and social development. This opportunity also brings with it raised expectations as well as conerns over the Government's ability to nmnage the enormous post-war reconstruction effort facing the country and to quickly succeed in: (i) consolidating peace and undertaking to disarm and demobilize approximately 45,000 combatants; (ii) resettling 150,000 IDPs and repatriating nearly 500,000 Sierra Leonean refugees from Guinea and Liberia; (iii) rehabilitating key elements of the country's rural infrastructure; (iv) providing material, financial and other inputs to Sierra Leonean farmers to encourage resettlement and the resumption of agricultural production; and (v) restoring basic social services, particularly primary health care and basic education. 5.4 This challenging post-conflict context provides the backdrop for the Bank's intervention. Current confidence in, and high expectations of, the Government may be replaced with frustration and skepticism if order and security are not reestablished, displaced populations are not reintegrated, and social and economic infiastucture is not rebuilt. Consequently, timely and adequate donor assistance is critical for longer-term economic development as well as social stability.
 TechnicalAnnex Project Titk: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Country: Sierra Leone Page 26 of 87 Strategy for Proposed Bank Assistance 5.5 IDA is a leading player in Sierra Leone, with projects in two sectors of central concern to the national recovery efforts- -inauct and health- and a Project Preparation Facility (PPF) for an institutional support Project in education. Furthermore, IDA is proposing to support macro-economic reform in Sierra Leone through an Economic Recovery Credit As such, IDA is well-positioned to support the Government's multi-sectoral reintegration and reconstruction efforts. Its involvement is further justified by the amount of resources required for the recovery programs, the poverty focus of the Project, the need to monitor the macro-economic impact of the process, and the shortened time frame within which an Emergency Recovery Credit can respond. 5.6 During the immediate post conflict period of two to three years, rapid progress on reintegration of ex-combatants, economic recovery and reconstruction, in the context of economic stability wili be essential to the long-term economic development of Sierra Leone. Therefore, post-conflict transition will be the central theme of IDA's assistance activities over the next few years. To this end, the proposed CRRP would serve as IDA's primary instrument to support rehabilitation, reconstruction and reintegration efforts in Sierra Leone, while the Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery Credit will address short-term balance of payment and budgetary support through a credit of USS 30.0 million. At the same time, the Integrated Health Sector Investment Project (Cr. 2827SL) is being restructured, and the Transport Sector Project (Cr. 2895-SL) is flexible enough to be adapted, to take account of the changing situation and emergency resource requirements of the country. 5.7 The Government has adopted a phased strategy to the implementation of the national recovery programs that has been instructed by post-conflict situations in Afiica and throughout the world. The first part of this phase will the improve the security situation through the structured disarmament and demobilization of approximately 45,000 ex-combatants, including members of the Armed Forces of Sierra Leone (AFSL), RUF and the Civil Defense Forces (CDF). The second part will address the short-term needs for social and economic reintegration and rehabilitation of ex-combatants and the vulnerable civilian population. The second development phase of the Government strategy would affect a progression from short- and medium-term reconstruction and recovery programs to longer-term development and poverty reduction through more traditional investment projects. Project Rationak 5.9 Security, social stability and future economic growth in Sierra Leone will depend, inter alia, on the successful demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants, the return of IDPs and refugees to their communities, and the revitalization of social and economic infrastructure. Therefore, the Project, designed to provide the needed immediate support for the reintegration of these groups and to strengthen the social and economic infiastructure in the communities most affected by the war, will play an important role in the process of continued recovery. It is felt that the social and economic reintegration of the target group lends itself well to IDA support because of the Bank's overall poverty focus in its lending program in Sierra Leone and elsewhere. 5.10 Furthermore, one of the underlying causes of the civil war and conflict over the past eight years has been the long-standing neglect of rural areas by the Central Government, resulting in a long-term decline of social services and infrastructure and growing disenchantment among large parts of the population. The Project will assist the process of redressing the urban bias in national development through a decenralized sub-project identification and implementation stregy, that should, if successful, rebuild confidence in GOSL's commitment and capacity to respond to the needs of the society as a whole. 5.11 The underlying Project concept of providing assistance to the internally displaced, refugees and ex-combatants, as well as to the receiving communities, is based on best practices and experiences gained in similar IDA member countries and post-conflict situations, and is deemed appropriate for achieving the development objective of the Project. The targeted public works program for the urban unemployed, and the training and employment efforts directed at ex- combatants are also based on successful Bank and other donor agency experiences in numerous countries. The Project design is based on a collaborative review and assessment of key socio- economic and other factors that have and will influence the emergency situation and recovery process. The review was carried out by the World Bank, Government, and major stakeholders in as thorough a fashion as possible given the changing security situation in-country during the last three years. THE MACRO-ECONOMIC FRAMEWORK Background and Introduction 7.1 By the late 1980's, Sierra Leone faced widespread poverty following nearly two decades of economic mismanagement. To address this problem, the government initiated an economic recovery program in late-1989 which sought to correct large macroeconomic imbalances and undertake structural reforms. In order to reestablish normal relations with external donors and creditors, the government adopted a rights accmulation program (RAP) with the International Monetary Fund in 1992. A Reconstruction Import Credit (RIC) was extended by the World Bank in 1992, followed by a Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) in 1993 as well as various sectoral credits. Stabilization gais were achieved and the groundwork was laid for major structural reforms, which brought renewed support from bilateral and multilateral donors. Upon completion of the RAP, Sierra Leone adopted a three-year Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) arrangement in March 1994. 7.2 Following large stabilization gains, the economy once again experienced a positive rate of growth in 1994 (Table 7.1). However, in early 1995, fighting between government and RUF forces escalated. The RUF overran the rutide and bauxite mines in January 1995, which at the time accounted for nearly 70 percent of Sierra Leone's official exports and 17 percent of government revenue. The spread of RUF attacks outside the eastern and southern provinces led to a fiuther large displacement of the population, loss in agricultural output, and disruption to major transport links. The heightening of the conflict was also a setback to macroeconomic stability. Inflation on a year-to-year basis jumped from 22 percent in 1994 to 35 percent in 1995. Likewise, the Leone depreciated by more than 50 percent. The loss of mining output and displacement of persons from firming activities led to a decline in real GDP by an estimated 10 percent.  TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Country: Sierra Leone Page 33 of 87 7.3 The Government's position strengthened somewhat in 1996 when it resorted to the use of the services of external military contractors to combat the rebels. The security situation improved correspondingly, and the economy began to show signs of recovery. Following multiparty elections in February and March 1996, prospects for economic recovery were bolstered by the new Government's commitment to macroeconomic stability and structural reform. As a result, real GDP is estimated to have grown by 5 percent in 1996 on the strength of a rebound in agricultural output and alluvial diamond mining activity. Inflation fell to 6 percent and the exchange rate remained stable. However, the key rutile and bauxite mining operations did not reopen as hoped for in 1996. As a result, the current account deficit (excluding grants) increased from 17.5 percent of GDP in 1994 to 21 percent in 1996. Nevertheless, the Bank of Sierra Leone was able to achieve a modest increase in gross international reserves to the equivalent of 1.5 months of imports, largely as a result of donor inflows. 7.4 The process of reconstruction was brought to an abrupt halt by the coup d'6tat staged by a handful of junior military officers in May 1997. There was a complete breakdown in the security situation, leading to increased lawlessness, destruction of property, and massive displacement of the population. Economic activity came to a virtual standstill with most businesses remaining closed after being looted. As a result, unemployment, already high before the coup, soared fiuther. Real GDP is estimated to have contracted by over 20 percent in 1997. Government finances deteriorated during the course of 1997 against the backdrop of a virtual cessation in mining revenues, a sharp reduction in customs revenues due to a trade embargo, and mounting expenditures on generally non-productive activities. The budget deficit on a commnitment basis increased to 7.4 percent of GDP compared to 6.3 percent of GDP in 1996. In the absence of external financing and a lack of domestic market for government debt instruments, public expenditures were funded largely by central bank financing. Inflation, which was about 6 percent on an annual basis at the time of the coup, surged to about 100 percent during the junta rule. Severe foreign exchange shortage as a result of cessation in mining activity and in donor-financed project and program aid led to a nearly 100 percent depreciation of the exchange rate, to over Le. 1,600 to the US Dollar. 7.5 The resolution of the crisis provided the opportnity for the restoration of normal economic activity. The Government resumed the implementation of its Resettlement, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (RRR) Program that received donor support at the Consultative Group meeting in March 1997 and that was reaffirmed with the return of the Government in March 1998. Furthermore, the Government re-launched the consultative process with a wide spectrum of civil society to elicit their input into a national development strategy for poverty reduction and sustainable economic growth. The main themes that emerged out of this Strategic Planning and Action Process (SPP) were: (i) creating a unified, peaceful nation with good governance; (ii) creating a strong, stable, and growing economy; and (iii) creating a nation of healthy, capable, and productive citizens. 7.6 After the return of Government in March 1998, economic activity resumed, with real GDP estimated to have increased by an estimated 1 percent for the year as a whole, after a sharp decline in 1997. Inflation dropped from 48.7 percent in the first quarter of 1998 to a negative 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter7. Although Government continued to experience serious institutional capacity constraints with regards to budgetary management, revenue collection rose significantly 7 The macroeconomic information on 1998 and 1999 is largely derived from the IMF Briefing Paper - Request for Emergency Post-Conflict Assistance, October 1999.

Macroeconomic Management 7.9 The Sierra Leonean authorities recopize that the restoration of macroeconomic stability, especially in the light of huge outlays required in the context of the RRR program, is critical for building business confidence and eliciting a strong private sector supply response. In view of this, they are currently elaborating a macroeconomic program with the IMF to ensure that the macroeconomic imbalances are reduced and that the emergency donor funding would be used efficiently. The main focus of the Govermnent policies during 2000 will be to elaborate and initiate macroeconomic and strucural reforms. The overarching objectives of the new macroeconomic framework will be to significantly reduce the rate of inflation while permitting a recovery in economic activity and a reconstitution of gross external reserves. These macroeconomic objectives will be pursued through prudent fiscal, monetary, as well as external trade policies in conformity with a market-determined exchange rate.  TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Countpy: Serra Leone Page 35 of 87 Fiscal Polies 7.10 The main objectives of the fiscal program in the medium term are to reduce significantly the overall budget deficit, improve the quality of expenditure, and pursue the social objectives of the RRR program. The Government recognizes that a reduction in the fiscal deficit is essential to maintaining price stability and steps are taken to strengthen fiscal discipline. An increased revenue effort will be undertaken and tight control over spending will be maintained. Previously initiated measures to strengthen expenditure control and monitoring will be reinforced. Improvement in revenue mobilization, will come from: (i) an improvement in tax administration, which will be pursued through the establishment of an independent revenue authority that would be remunerated on the basis of performance; stricter enforcement in the customs and excise department; greater monitoring of freight levy; and better collection of revenues from fisheries; and (ii) changes in the tax structure to improve compliance: this will be approached through introduction of new income tax legislation that will be geared to a more equitable distribution of the tax burden and would lower tax rates. Further, the Government is considering measures to broaden the tax base (with technical assistance from the IMF). Specific fiscal targets are expected to be set in collaboration with the IMF mission. Monetary and Financial Sector Policies 7.11 The Bank of Sierra Leone (BSL) will pursue a monetary policy aimed at substantially reducing the rate of monetary expansion and lowering inflation in line with the above mentioned macroeconomic targets. Credit expansion to the private sector is being encouraged. The policy priority in the financial sector is to ensure that commercial bank portfolios are restructured to restore profitability and to conform with prudential guidelines. The reform will aim at creating a more stable and viable financial system by improving banking supervision and oversight by BSL, expanding available savings instruments, and promoting growth and competition in the provision of financial services. Specifically, the revised Banking and Bank of Sierra Leone Acts, which are expected to be introduced in Parliament, should allow for improved banking supervision, strengthened prudential requirements, increased minimum capital requirements, and appropriate guidelines for classifying loans and issuing new tradable instruments. Edernal Sector Polices 7.12 The Government intends to contain the current account deficit within limits that can be financed through budgetary and balance of payments assistance, and consistent with the naintenance of a modest level of gross external reserves. The current account deficit is expected to rise to 16 percent of GDP, while gross reserves are targeted to amount to US$35 million at the end-December 2000. GOSL will negotiate with extemal creditors to reach agreement on the outstanding extenal debt service arrears. The current market determined exchange rate will be mainained and measures will be put in place to narrow the gap between the official and the parallel market rate. 7.13 On trade policy, the Government will continue to maintain a liberalized trade system, diversify exports, and promote efficient import substitution activities. The range of duty rates will be narrowed, with the lowest rate of 5 percent, applied to raw materials, spare parts, plant and machinery, and essential capital goods, the rate of 20 percent applied to intermediate and semi-manufactured goods, and the highest rate of 40 percent applied to luxury goods. The tariff regime will be reviewed to bring it more in line with the unfolding tariff reductions in neighboring countries. A duty drawback system for non-traditional exports is likely to be

COMMUNITY REINTEGRATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECT Project Description 9.1 The Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project (CRRP), which seeks US$25 million equivalent IDA financing, will support the GOSL's emergency recovery programs (the NRRRP and the NDDRP) by assisting those people and communities most affected by the past eight years of conflict to rebuild their communities and resume normal productive lives. The Project will consist of two components: (i) an Emergency Recovery Support Fund (ERSF), and related institutional support to the NCRRR and partners; and (ii) a Training & Employment Program (TIEP), and related institutional support to NCDDR and partners. ERSF and Related Intiutional Suppoit 9.2 The ERSF will facilitate the social and economic recovery of communities and the restoration of basic social and economic services through demand-driven, community-oriented projects that target internally displaced persons, refugees and the communities affected by the conflict of the past eight years. The ERSF will finance sub-projects in the areas of agricultural rehabilitation, temporary shelter, reconstruction of community infrastructure, establishment of essential social services, promotion of reconciliation, and local institutional capacity building that target IDPs, refugees and the communities to which they return. The ERSF wiln also support labor-intensive urban and rural public works programs that help rehabilitate economic and social assets, and which provide a temporary social safety net for specifically targeted vulnerable groups of unemployed youth, ex-combatants, and others. Sub-projects would range in cost from US$ 10,000 to US$500,000 equivalent, and would be implemented by eligible partners, including internaonal and national NGOs, line ministry units, existing project units, and community-based organizations which have adequate capacity. 9.3 As part of the ERSF sub-projects, IDA would finance the cost of equipment and vehicles, basic agricultural inputs, construction materials, traiing, technical assistance, and essential operating costs associated with sub-project implementation. In addition, IDA would finance a portion of the recurrent costs associated with sub-project administration, monitoring and evaluation on the part of the Government. Detailed and satisfactory systems, procedures, standardized guidelines and formats have been developed by GOSL and are presented in the '"ERSF Operational Manual". The African Development Bank will co-finance with IDA the ERSF, institutional support of NCRRR, and related project management costs under this component of the CRRP. GOSL is discussing the possibility of additional support to the Fund with other donor agencies. TEP andRelated Ins_ituional Support 9.4 The TEP will support the social and economic reintegration of former combatants through targeted counseling, training, and employment initiatives. The social reintegration efforts would include civic education, socio-psychological counseling and community sensitization
 Technical Annex Project Title: Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation County: Sierra Leone Page 40 of 87 activities. Counseling and referrals would prepare ex-combatants for their return to civilian life and assist them by providing critical psycho-social support during the reintegration phase and by providing information and opportunities to access available reintegration assistance. The economic reintegration services would include a vocational orientation, counseling on job- seeking strategies, information and advice on training and employment opportunities and on establishing micro-projects. The TEP program would also offer concrete means for linking ex- combatants to trauning and employment opportunities, including the referral to labor-intensive public works, broader rehabilitation projects, income generating activities, vocational training and apprenticeships. 9.5 In the area of vocational training the program would encourage existing training suppliers to prepare and implement short, modular training courses that correspond to the educational background and career interests of the ex-combatants (based on a socio-economic profile compiled at the time of registration), and the needs of the labor market. Skills development will be provided through a contract training scheme with training providers. Rehabilitation of vocational training infiastructure would also be required during the pilot phase of the program. Once training capacity has been re-established, the introduction of voucher programs may be encouraged to ensure that the training is sufficiently demand-driven and to enable ex-combatants to purchase the training that will increase their employability. The TEP will also finance training expenses incurred by artisans who train ex-combatants through informal sector apprenticeships; tool-kits would be provided upon commencement of the apprenticeship or after completion of the vocational training to increase the employability of ex-combatants. 9.6 ERSF and TEP activities will be implemented by eligible partners including international and national NGOs, government line ministry units, existing project units and community-based organizations where capacity warrants. The sub-project implementation procedures have been designed through a process of investigation, consultation, and consensus-building initiated by the Govemment, the World Bank and others in mid-1996. Over a six-month period Government staff regional authorities, national and international NGOs, and key international agencies and donors currently involved in the rehabilitation and recovery process were consulted on how best such a funding mechanism should work. This collaborative process aulminated in a set of consultative meetings of Ministry staff, NGO representatives and key donors held in November 1996 and May 1997 to finalize these procedures. The result of this consultative process is the shared understanding of the rationale behind the proposed administrative procedures and a shared responsibility among the group involved in the process for the successful implementation of the fund. It is believed that this participatory planning process will help ensure the viability of the Project. 9.7 The ERSF will rely on a decentralized, bottom-up project planning, approval and monitoring process which taps into and builds upon existing systems and structures at the regional and local levels. Implementing partners will be called upon to design sub-projects in close collaboration with village, section and chiefdom authorities. Regional inter-agency committees and regional NCRRR and NCDDR staff will oversee individual project selection and monitoring activities. NCRRR and NCDDR headquarters' staff will provide the broad policy and program planning fiamework for the CRRP, monitor national CRRP implementation and coordinate overall recovery efforts. A national level Projects Committee will be constituted to review and approve sub-projects that are valued at US$50,000, or more, are national in scope, or that target the Western Area. The TEP will utilize a standard requests for proposal system as well as a demand-driven project identification process similar to the ERSF to select and finance reintegration sub-projects for ex-combatants. Areas of CRRP Activity 9.10 In line with the overall objectives of the NRRRP and the NDDRP, the CRRP will support interventions and sub-projects which address the following broad sectors and areas of activity: * Agricultural Rehabilitation: including support to basic productive activities (primarily through the provision of seeds, tools and emergency food supply for the farming season); support to rehabilitation of tree crops, other cash crops, fishing (through the provision of equipment) and animal husbandry (through re-stocking of animals); * Shelter: principally to provide temporary structures and to provide the planning framework for permanent facilities; * Rehabilitation of Community Infrastructure: to support the rehabilitation of schools, health centers, court barmes (traditional vi1lage admnitatve structure), water supply, roads, nrual market-places and other priority structures as identified by communities; * Re-establishment of Essential Services: to provide human and material resources essential to the re-establishment of basic health and education services in collaboration with the relevant ministries; * Reintegration of Vulnerable Groups: supporting the social and economic reintegration of specific groups (e.g., widows, female head of households, ex- combatants, children affected by the war and disabled people) into communities; which may include temporary safety nets, community sensitization, vocational training capital/credit, counselingftrauma healing, information, employment (e.g. labor-intensive public works), education and/or functional literacy; * Promotion of Reconciliation: for programs promoting reconciliation and conflict resolution at the community level; which may include developing conflict resolution
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration andRehabilitation Counhy: Sierra Leone Page 43 of 87 skills, promoting reconciliation through local media, supporting youth, community and voluntary associations with the potential for promoting reconciliation; * Small Enterprise Promotion and Vocational Training Schemes: designed to support development of productive skills among individual target group members (particularly ex-combatants) and to promote income generating activities at community level; * Public works program targeting unemployed groups in the poorest sections of Freetown, provincial capitals and for rural reconstruction in areas such as: environmental sanitation and waste disposal, road repair and maintenance, public buildings maintenance, urban reforestation, etc.; and * Capacity-Building: of local organizations in all of the above areas the development. Geographic and Beneficiary Targeting 9.11 The CRRP will be active throughout the regions and districts of Sierra Leone which have been affected by the war. Priority will be given to supporting populations returning to rural areas, and for those areas most severely affected by the war. 9.12 The CRRP will coordinate closely with other recovery activities (e.g. the European Comnmission's Resettlement and Rehabilitation Program, line-ministry emergency plans, NGO initiatives, etc.) so as to avoid duplication and overlap in areas of operation. The procedures for sub-projec review and approval will also support similar sub-project activities financed by the ADB-supported Social Action and Poverty Alleviation (SAPA) Program, which is also managed by NCRRR. 9.13 To be eligible for consideration, any sub-project proposal presented to the CRRP must target one of the following groups: (i) people in war-affected villages who never moved but are takin initiatives to re-establish themselves and their communities; (ii) people returning sotaneously to their villages from displaced camps, bush camps and other areas; (iii) vulnerable groups, such as female headed households, children affected by the conflict through being orphaned, war trana or disrupted schooling, and disabled people, including those severely injured or trumatzed by the war; (iv) ex-combatants and their dependents; and (v) urban unemployed. Institutional Support to NCRRR and NCDDR 9.14 The National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation is charged with coordinating and monitoring the NRRRP. While NCRRR is a temporary institution, it is also newly established and requires support to effectively carry out its mandate, particularly in relation to the CRRP. Therefore, the proposed Project would strengthen NCRRR's efforts to coordinate, monitor and facilitate implementation of priority recovery activities through the provision of essential goods, equipment and support of recurrent costs for central and regional offices. In addition, the Credit would finance technical assistance in the areas of financial management, procurement, auditing, management information systems, ERSF implementation assistance, and project evaluation. IDA will share the cost of supporting NCRRR with the AfDB, UNDP and the Government. 9.15 The National Committee on Disannament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR) is also a newly established governmental institution with a- temporary mandate of three years.

STUDIES AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE Preparatory Studies Completed 10.1 The studies and consultancies described below have been undertaken by and on behalf of Govemment in order to facilitate the preparation of the CRR. Social and Economic Reintegration andResource Management: A Study on Conflict andReconciiaion. 10.2 This qualitative study examined three main issues: (i) potential conflict over land and land based resources in the context of large scale civilian resettlement; (ii) community perceptions of the demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants; and (iii) operational strategies to revitalize and support the capacities of community structures to deal with conflict resolution. The analysis indicated that the displaced felt that there would be very little conflict over land allocation, with the possible exception of areas with tree crops where resettlement needs would have to be coordinated closely by local authorities. 10.3 Regarding the demobilization and reintegration of ex-ombatants, interviews undertaken revealed that while some recognize the need for reconciliation others were fearfil about having ex-combatants in their communities. These fears could be allayed if a proper community sensitization process is implemented to inform people about the scope and coverage of the demobilization and reintegration process. The study further examines operational strategies to re- establish and support the capacities of community structures to deal with conflict resolution. A significant reform of the judicial system was recommended, as well as a sensitization process, at the local judiciary level and among paramount chiefs. Reintegration of War-Affected Youth and Ex-Combatants: A Study of the Social and Economic Opportunity Structure in Sierra Leone. 10.4 This study, undertaken in October 1996, assessed the motivation and needs of war- affected youth and ex-combatants and analyzed social and economic opportunity structures currently existing in Sierra Leone. The study highlights that: i. most young people have become entrapped by the fighting rather than volunteering for action; ii. the total numbers of irregular combatants are not that large, and therefore demobilization could be relatively straightforward; and iii. hard core RUF combatants, particularly those with a track record for violent atrocities, fear that they will become targets for civilian revenge. However, many combatants spoke of a desire to be reunited with their families and to retum to school or complete disrupted education.
 TechnicalAnnex Project Title: Community Reintegration andRehabilitahon Country: Sierra Leone Page 47of 87 Socio-Economic Survey of theArmed Forces of the Republic of Sierra Leone 10.5 A socio-economic survey of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Sierra Leone (AFRSL) was undertaken between December 1996 and January 1997 to gather statistically useful data on the needs, characteristics and aspirations of nilitary personnel with a view to informing the design of Government reintegration measures. Quantitative data was supplemented by qualitative information gathered in focus group discussions, which sought further information on needs and the civilian aspirations of AFRSL personnel. The main findings of the survey were that: i. AFRSL personnel are predominately male (98.1%), under thirty years of age (56.2%), and married (96%); ii. the majority of the forces (61.8%) have only served for up to 5 years; iii. education rates are relatively high by Sierra Leone standards (only 29.2% had never been to school, and 30% had completed secondary education); iv. if discharged, over 75% of members of the AFRSL would return to their home communities, where they expected that family members would be the main source of initial assistance; and v. the lack of employment opportunities was cited by 54.9% of those interviewed as being the major concem upon demobilization. Respondents also identified professional training as a vital need after demobilization. Some respondents expressed a wish for agricultural tuining. 10.6 GOSL will augment these findings with the data currently being collected as part of the DDR registration process underway at Lungi Camp, as the Government designs appropriate reintegration strategies. The Operational Manual specifies the roles and responsibilities of both NCRRR and its implementing partners to access and monitor the use of funds available under the ERSF The manual, contained in the Project File, also provides the standard forms, guidelines, evaluation critena and contacts for implementation of the Fund.
