 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 5: Page I of 15 TORS: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PROCUREMENT UNIT (DRAFT) Background Subsequent to the restoration of democracy and the revival of recovery efforts following more than seven years of civil war and unrest, the Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL) is embarking on an ambitious program of activities for national recovery and reintegration that will be supported by the World Bank, the African Development Bank, the UK Department for International Development, and other donor organizations. The National Programmes for: (i) Reconstruction, Rehabilitation and Resettlement (RRR) and for (ii) Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration (DDR) will facilitate and finance reintegration support for ex-combatants and resettlement of refugees and displaced people, rehabilitation of social and economic infrastructure, local institutional capacity building and reconciliation assistance. Two institutions will be the principal executing agencies under the World Bank, AfDB and other donor supported projects: the National Commission for Rehabilitation, Reconstruction, and Resettlement (NCRRR) and the National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (NCDDR). Both agencies are newly established and are temporary institutions that will serve for a finite period of time to set the overall policy for the national programmes; ensure adequate and appropriate coordination among and between relevant governmental, non- governmental, and donor partners; and monitor implementation of specific sub-project activities. Partner organizations including local and international non-governmental organizations, community based organizations, UN agencies, line ministry departments, and private business will take principal responsibility for the implementation of the project as sub-contractors. The NCRRR will seek to facilitate national reconstruction activities through a demand driven social- fund type financing mechanism (the Emergency Recovery Support Fund-- ERSF) that will support community based sub-projects aimed at restoring economic and social infrastructure, promoting reconciliation, and strengthening local institutions. Appropriate sub-projects will be identified by war-affected populations and communities and designed and implemented in collaboration with local and international NGOs, line ministries and other partners active and experienced in the geographic and sectoral areas of concern. NCRRR, working through district-level officers, regional offices, and inter-agency committees, will review and approve sub-project proposals, enter into contract agreements with various implementing partners, and monitor the physical and financial progress of sub-project implementation. The NCDDR will oversee the GOSL commitment and efforts to completly disarm, demobilise and reintegrate (i) an estimated 8,000 combatants of the Armed Forces of Sierra Leone (AFSL) and the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) currently under Government control and (ii) an estimated 25,000 combatants of the Civil Defence Forces (CDF). The primary objectives are the consolidation of security and the sustainable social and economic reintegration of ex-combatants. The disarmament,
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 5: Page 2 of 15 demobilisation and reintegration programme if implemented in a transparent and equitable manner, could serve as an important pull factor for those combatants still holding out in the bush, provided a conductive security environment is promoted. The Executive Secretariat of the NCDDR would be responsible for ensuring: (i) the planning and implementation of the individual programme components in collaboration with other government departments, NGOs and donors; (ii) the transparent and accountable administration of the programme; and (iii) monitoring and evaluation. An important financial and management control aspect of the DDR Programme will be the payment of reintegration allowances to all ex-combatants noted above, and contracting and support for a training and employment fund. NCRRR and NCDDR are new institutions with limited experience administering donor-financed project activities. In addition, the Government recognizes the need for the highest degree of transparency and accountability in the operation and administration of the national programmes to: (i) satisfy the requirements of donor agencies considering financial support to the GOSL efforts; (ii) encourage implementing partners to continue collaborating with the Commission and the Committee in the national recovery and reintegration process; and (iii) to reassure the public in general as to the seriousness and commitment of the Government in redressing the damage and causes of the civil war. Therefore, the GOSL intends to seek local and international technical expertise to implement the financial management and procurement responsibilities for the Emergency Recovery Support Fund and other donor-financed activities and support to the NCRRR and NCDDR. Proposals will be sought from a short-list of qualified local and international firms. The successful bidder will set-up and manage the Financial Management and Procurement Unit (FMPU). This unit will have responsibility for all financial management functions, contracting, and procurement procedures on behalf of the NCRRR and NCDDR. All costs associated with setting up and operating the FMPU will be defined by the bidders and should be included in the Financial Proposal. The bidders will have complete responsibility for identifying and hiring all local and international staff deemed necessary to fulfil the responsibilities of the FMPU. The unit will be managed by a qualified and experienced senior professional with experience in the design and implementation of an appropriate financial management and internal control system for the Project and Programme of this nature. Additional staff of accountants and other professionals will be required as necessary to assist with disbursement, accounting, expenditure reviews, internal control and project and sub-project procurement issues. An illustrative list of professional staff for the FMPU is presented in these TORs, however the specific staffing arrangements for the unit are at the discretion of the consultant firm bidding on these services. The remaining pages outline in greater detail the terms of reference for the Financial Management and Procurement Unit; required qualifications of manditory and recommended staff; and the timing, duration, and duty post for the unit's staff. 1. Overall Responsibilities The Financial Management and Procurement Unit (FMPU) will support the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation (NCRRR) and the National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR) in all aspects of financial management, accounting, contracting and procurement related to the GOSL's National Programmes. The unit will be responsible for the following:
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 5: Page 3 of 15 1. Develop appropriate financial management and procurement policies and procedures (to include standard formats, guidelines, etc.) in line with Government, and donors policies and procedures; implement and enforce an adequate control system; and provide training and support to NCRRR and NCDDR HQ and regional offices staff in their implementation. 2. Design and set up a computerized financial management system (using off-the-shelf software) that will provide for the adequate capture, analysis, and reporting of financial information in an accurate and timely fashion for all funds and accounts allocated to NCRRR and NCDDR for which FMPU will have full responsibility to manage. The system should be design to handle various donors accounts (special accounts of the World Bank and AfDB, Donors pool account, etc.) and to segregate all transactions and reporting by category and by source. 3. Review all disbursements requests submitted by suppliers and implementing agencies for goods and services provided to NCRRR and NCDDR and ensure propriety and eligibility. 4. Effect payments to appropriate contractors and suppliers for goods and services (including implementing partner sub-contracts) upon authorization by NCRRR and NCDDR and verification of the availability of funds. 5.  Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page I of 14 DDR Program: Reintegration Component; Considerations and Technical Assistance Needs 1. Background The GOSL has demonstrated solid commitment to the DDR as evidenced by a credible process, shaped by clear and consistent policy pronouncement, supported with a functioning policy committee unit and an Executive Secretariat - both constituting the institutional framework for managing and coordinating the DDR program. However limited financial resources and sporadic incursions by the rebel forces represent major challenges to the initiation of a comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration program. Compounding the process is the urgency of time, which holds out the inevitable option of a planning and implementation depth atypical of conventional DDR programs. Designed to take place in a very difficult socio-economic environment, the process offers limited possibilities for creating stable livelihoods in the short term. Consequently, the envisaged reintegration of 2,200 members of the ex-AFSL and the captured/surrendered members of the RUF currently encamped in Lungi garrison, is fraught with a considerable number of complexities. The process of initial military screening, registration, socio-economic profiling of the target groups, pre- discharge orientation activities (socio-psychological counseling, civic education as well as vocational and skills orientation) and discharge are planned to take place between August 1998 and January 1999 - a five month timeframe considered insufficient by any standard. Although the cumulative and extended period of encampment has engendered an intense and restless feeling of uneasiness among the combatants, it has also fostered an expectation of quick discharge and reintegration into civilian life - an expectation that cannot be overlooked in the planning and implementation of the reintegration process. The reintegration component of the DDR program is envisioned to be an integral part of an overall national reconciliation and reconstruction strategy. It is proposed that demobilization will take place in three phases, between July 1998 and January 2000. Phase I, referring to the currently detained AFSL/RUF ex-combatants in Lungi (LDC), was scheduled for July 1998 to January 1999. However, to facilitate the reintegration of these ex-combatants into civilian life a concerted effort needs to be put in place, involving all stakeholders, to develop a careful and realistic strategy which can be implemented in the very near future. In this respect the Government of Sierra Leone faces considerable challenges. These challenges need to be met to avoid the many risks associated with re-entry of ex-combatants into a civilian society devastated and traumatized by a protracted and destructive civil war. The planning process of the DDR reintegration component will address two immediate issues. Firstly, a series of activities need to be in place at LDC to ensure that the already started demobilization and reintegration process of ex-AFSL in the camp can proceed in an appropriate and meaningful manner. It should be recalled that prior to the launching of the improved camp management and the provision of food and other basic needs by DFID considerable tension had been building up in and around LDC. Recent improvement of living conditions and the ongoing registration and profiling exercise have improved the morale in LCD. A failure to follow through with concrete social and economic reintegration
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 2 of 14 initiatives during the encampment period may have a great impact on the success or failure of the entire demobilization process. The social and political viability of the remainder of the DDRP could therefore be at risk. Secondly, a detailed and credible plan for the reinsertion and reintegration of the subsequent phases of the DDRP needs to be developed. This plan needs to take into account the significant different starting points for social and economic reintegration for the ex-AFSL, ex-RUF and ex-CDF combatants, respectively. The design and planning of the social and economic reintegration measures needs to be consistent with the following overall principles: * Targeted assistance to ex-combatants will only be provided during the reinsertion phase; * From the outset, longer-term reintegration assistance to ex-combatants will make optimal use of the mechanisms established under the RRR; * Assistance to vulnerable groups such as female ex-combatants, disabled ex-combatants and child ex-combatants needs to utilize and strengthen the existing in-country capacity of organizations already on the ground. 2. Strategy Framework for Social and Economic Reintegration To prepare the ex-combatants adequately for their re-entry into civilian life, the DDR reintegration framework needs to incorporate the following components: * Social reintegration, including both socio-psychological counseling and civic education; * These components are intended to address psychological factors, which distort patterns of behavior while providing the ex-combatants with positive attitudes towards civic responsibilities, respect for democratic culture and skills for conflict resolution. Economic reintegration, including vocational and post-discharge orientation. The focus of economic reintegration is to equip the ex-combatants with productive skills and options for employment as effective means to successful transition to civilian life. The proposed Training and Employment Fund, employment-intensive public works and promotion of artisan enterprise development are variety of programs designed to serve this purpose and provide linkage with the emergency recovery social fund. Community sensitization and information campaign: * A major precondition for successful reintegration of ex-combatants is the receptiveness of their various communities regarding their return and resettlement. Pervasive feelings of mistrust, animosity and other forms of social tension engendered by war calls for a systematic process of re-engineering social relationships and perceptions. Conversely, to accommodate reintegration of ex-combatants, specific attitudinal transformation needs to be inculcated in the returning ex-combatants to prepare them for eventual reintegration in the local communities. These processes require the design of a comprehensive program of community sensitization and information dissemination. Within the context of the DDR program, an Information and Community Sensitization is anticipated to focus on (i) the ex-combatants currently encamped in Lungi; (ii) the intended communities of return; (iii) as well as a nationwide audience. Detailed planning for each component needs to be developed within a couple of weeks with overlapping and incremental implementation process. The constraints of
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 3 of 14 time not only demand concurrent planning but also simultaneous implementation of the strategy components. 3. Analysis of expectation and target group profiles During the registration of the ex-combatants a short socio-economic profile will be established. These socio-economic profiles form the baseline infornation on educational background, professional experience and future professional expectations of the ex-combatants. The analysis of these profiles should provide useful information to the reintegration planners and implementers in terms of areas of district of re-settlement, the requirements to facilitate return to the respective districts, intended occupations and relevant skills requirements. The socio-economic data collected from the registration process and from the rapid inventory of skills among the ex-combatants are essential to program both social and economic reintegration initiatives. Convergence of skills with chosen district of settlement and opportunities for employment in the local labor market are crucial in achieving anticipated results of any vocational improvement and employment generation program. 4. Training needs assessment and identification of skills gaps To support the social and economic reintegration process it is further recommended to carry out a rapid training needs assessment in the formal and informal sectors of the Sierra Leone economy. This training needs assessment could be carried out through an establishment survey and/or through the use of rapid urban and rural appraisal techniques. Parallel to this training needs assessment a rapid appraisal of economic opportunities could be carried out. More insight into the skill requirements of the labor market and potential market niches will enable the ex-combatants to make a more informed choice regarding their employment and income generating opportunities. This type of assessment would also inform training providers about the current level and quantity of skills demand, identify the skill gaps and facilitate the design of means to fill these gaps. 5. Local implementation capacity and requirement for upgrading A rapid assessment of local capacity will provide a valid basis for a rational choice of implementing partners in the reintegration program. The capacity of existing local institutions to deliver the required program for skills improvement and to participate in the reconstruction and rehabilitation program remains unclear. Considerable looting and destruction of the facilities of most local institutions remains a major constrain. This becomes obvious when contrasted against the sizeable capital investment required to upgrade their equipment. Under the current time constraints, the mission recommends to initiate immediate pilot activities to test the potential for upgrading capacity of local institutions to provide on- site training orientation and other components of the reintegration program for the phase 1 operation in Lungi. However, balancing the requirement for upgrading of local institutional capacity against the exigency of engaging foreign expertise remains a delicate decision that will influence the quality, time and cost of program delivery. Technical Assistance will be required to assist in the design of program and management of the process.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 4 of 14 6. Options for reintegration During the encampment the possibilities for organizing an extensive skills training program will be limited due to the time constraints under which the reintegration program is being developed. However, the data and information to be derived from the socio-economic profiles, the economic opportunities and training needs assessment, and the assessment of local implementation capacities are essential building blocks for developing an appropriate vocational orientation program for the ex-combatants. The vocational orientation would have to be planned and implemented with the assistance of local training providers who have developed or are in the process of developing tailor-made short courses for ex- combatants. Within the framework of this orientation, the possibility of organizing on-site workshops and on-site trade exhibitions would have to be explored with those training providers. Such workshops or such an exhibition of the use and content of a variety of skills would facilitate a more informed career choice for the ex-combatants. A more comprehensive training program will be developed and provided within the context of the Training and Employment Fund. After the discharge, a rmenu of different social and economic reintegration options could be available to the ex-combatants. Recent plans for reintegration assistance in other post-conflict situations have included all, a combination of or some of the following: - Rehabilitation of basic social, economic and physical infrastructure; Revitalization of basic social services; * Community-based rural development programs; L Labor-intensive public works programs; - Agricultural programs - Skill development in technical and/or entrepreneurial skills to facilitate employment or self- employment (including apprenticeships); - Adult education (literacy, numeracy, life-skills, etc.); * Self-employment through the creation of small and micro enterprises; * Provision of micro-credit, self-employment tool kits, and support services (counseling and guidance, job placement, etc.) for assisting reintegration into different activities; * Targeted activities for vulnerable groups, such as, disabled ex-combatants, child soldiers, etc.; Within the context of the DDR reintegration component, it is important to recommend realistic options to the ex-combatants. DDR will therefore be responsible for the provision of counseling and referral services at the regional and district level, which will provide ex-combatants with information about potential opportunities for employment, participation in the private sector, and community-based reconstruction and rehabilitation activities. It is important to note that in principle the implementation strategy of the CRRP is to use a community-based demand driven project identification and development process. Ex-combatants will additionally have access to an employment, vocational training and apprenticeship fund known as the regional Training and Employment Fund (TEF). The TEF will facilitate access to apprenticeships or other skills training, and will subsidize employment opportunities where possible. As far as post-discharge social reintegration is concerned, a community sensitization and information campaign for ex-combatants, communities and the general public will be essential. This has already been emphasized by GOSL as an issue of overarching importance. Important steps have been taken so far, including public announcement of the terms and conditions of the DDRP as well as a high profile televised debate and information program on the DDRP.  Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 6 of 14 Draft Terms of Reference Reinsertion and Reintegration Unit Manager National Committee for Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR) Executive Secretariat Background In June 1998, following more than seven years of civil war and illegal junta rule, the recently reinstated Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL) took the initiative to develop a comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration (DDR) program aimed at dealing with an estimated 35,000 ex-combatants including members of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), Armed Forces of sierra Leone, and the Civil Defense Forces. Considerable progress was made to initiate work under this DDR program during the last six months, however, an upsurge in fighting in late 1998, culminating in an attack on and battle for Freetown in early January 1999, resulted in the suspension of the program. ECOMOG forces were able to re-establish security in Freetown and Western region and cleared major highways to allow access to the country. Subsequent to the attack on Freetown, there is a growing understanding that for sustainable long- term peace and security in the country, a political settlement is preferable. Consequently the UN, in concert with major bilateral partners, facilitated a peace negotiation between rebel leader Sankoh and RUF commanders as well as the Government and other Rebel groups. The outcome was the Lome Peace Agreement which provided the basis for a negotiated settlement to the conflict. Under the specific provision of the agreement, the United Nation Military Observer Mission (UNOMSIL) and Monitoring Group of West African States (ECOMOG) will enforce cease fire and oversee the disarmament, demobilization of all surrendered forces as part of the comprehensive DDR program. In anticipation of a rapid resolution of the current conflict, international partners of the GOSL made committments to assist the Government re-start and plan for the expansion of its' DDR Program. The Program is seen as crucial in moving forward the recently negotiated peace agreement, sustain a viable cease-fire agreement as well as provide vital momentum to sustainable peace and longer-term security. Specifically, long-term technical assistance position would be required to manage the various aspects of the Reintegration measures which have been identified to support successful return of demobilised ex-combatants under the DDR program of the Executive Secretariat of the NCDDR. Given the special nature of the DDR responsibilities, and the lack of in-country experience in these areas, as well as to maintain credibility and neutrality in the program, it is recommended that selected candidate will serve as unit technical manager in the related area and maintain overall responsibility for the day to day management of the program of their respective units within Executive Secretariat of NCDDR to which they will be attached. The responsibilities outline below represent the broad terms of reference for the Reinsertion and Reintegration Unit Manager. Context The purpose of the DDR Program is to facilitate the process whereby combatants from both sides of the conflict gradually and peacefully return to normal and productive civilian lives. Specifically, the DDR would finance activities aimed at disarming and demobilizing combatants (including registration, medical screening, and socio-economic profiling, pre-discharge orientation programs), providing reinsertion assistance (including departure allowances, transitional safety net allowance and facilitating access to land) and reintegration support (including vocational and/or non-formal education, apprenticeships, information and referral services, counseling, community relations and civic education).
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 7 of 14 An effective Reinsertion and Reintegration program would provide for ex-combatants opportunities to become productive members of their home communities. The opportunities would involve activities in support of social and economic reintegration assistance beginning with the pre-discharge orientation activities during demobilization, transitional allowances upon discharge and training, employment and self employment upon settlement in home communities. The candidate should respond with great degree of flexibility and creativity to the fast changing conditions on the ground. Objective To oversee the design and implementation of the Reinsertion and Reintegration program for approximately 45,000 ex-combatants, that is aimed to facilitate their return to civilian life and consolidate the peace and security and form the basis for post-war community reintegration and rehabilitation in close consultation and co-ordination with NCRRR. Responsibilities: The Reinsertion and Reintegration unit Manager will report directly to the Executive Secretary , in consultation with the chief technical advisor and other unit managers, maintain close working relationship and co-operations with UN Agencies (ILO, WFP, UNDP, and UNICEF) NGOs, firms, and traditional leadership. The R&R Unit Manager will be responsible for the definition, implementation, management, and evaluation as well as revision of strategies aimed at facilitating the social, psychological and economic reintegration of all eligible ex-combatants under the Government's DDR Program. The Unit manager will manage day to day operation of the reinsertion and reintegration program as well as design specific measure for promoting incremental assumption of line responsbility by a suitably identified local counterpart. Specifically, the incumbent will be responsible to: 1.  Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 7: Page 10 of 14 Community Sensitization Specialist NCDDR / NCRRR Draft Terms of Reference Background: A major precondition for successful reintegration of ex-combatants is the receptiveness of their various communities regarding their return and resettlement. Pervasive feelings of mistrust, animosity and other forms of social tension engendered by war demand the establishment of a systematic process of re- establishing social relationships and perceptions. Conversely, to accommodate the reintegration of ex- combatants, specific attitudinal transformation needs to be inculcated in the returning ex-combatants to prepare them for eventual reintegration in the local communities. These processes require the design of a comprehensive program of community sensitization and information dissemination. Within the context of the DDR program, an Information and Community Sensitization specialist will be required to assist the Executive Secretariat of the NCDDR and the NCRRR in the planning and design of an information and sensitization campaign. The campaign will target (i) the ex-combatants currently encamped in Lungi (ii) the intended communities of return (iii) as well as nationwide audience. Initially, the task will cover a period of six weeks, starting from the second week of September 1998. If necessary, a follow-up mission might be necessary to evaluate the impact and fine-tune the sensitization and reintegration program. The assignment will outline activities for raising social awareness and civic responsibilities and will essentially include the following: (i) an assessment of existing local capacities and the framework for coordination of the process; (ii) the design of a comprehensive national strategy on reconciliation and social rehabilitation; (iii) the development of broad content and message and (iv) the identification of credible mechanism for the delivery of message. Duties and Responsibilities: The specific responsibilities of the specialist will comprise the following: * Analyze the capacity and identify potential implementing agencies in the field of information and community sensitization. * Direct the preparation of comprehensive national strategy for community sensitization. * Assist implementation agencies in designing target specific programs of re-engineering social conception regarding the ex-combatants and other war-affected groups. * Workout strategies for collaboration with national and international agencies currently operating in the field of community sensitization. * Assess and review the effectiveness of the message and content of the community sensitization program as well as ascertain the effectiveness of the medium of information dissemination. * Develop terms of reference, procedures, criteria and performance indicators as the basis for contracting implementing agencies and monitoring results. * Assist in the review and identification appropriate programs of community sensitization. * Elaborate implementation plans, phasing and the budgets for the Executive Secretariat.

 TechnicalAnnex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 8: Page I of 4 TORs: Project Financial Audit Objective The objective of the audit of the Program Financial Statement (PFS) is to enable the auditor to express a professional opinion on the financial position of the various donors funds (World Bank, AfDB, other Donors) allocated to the National Resettlement, Reconstruction, and Rehabilitation Program and managed by the Financial Management and Procurement Unit (FMPU) at each fiscal year, semi-annually for three (3) years, starting from June 30, 1999. The auditor is also required to express separate opinions on the Statement of Expenditures (SOEs) and the Special Accounts (SA) for the funds received and expenditures occurred for the accounting period ended at the same dates. It is also expected to express separate opinions on the accounts for other donors according to their reporting requirements. The program accounts (books of account) provide the basis for preparation of the PFS and are established to reflect the financial transactions in respect of the program, as maintained by the FMPU. Scope The audit will be carried out in accordance with International Standards of Auditing, and will include such tests and controls as the auditor considers necessary under the circumstances. In addition, the auditor should pay special attention to the following: (a) All external funds have been used in accordance with the conditions of the relevant financing agreements, with due attention to economy and efficiency, and only for the purposes for which the financing was provided. Relevant financing agreement are the IDA Credit No ............. of US$ . for 3 years, the ADF Loan No. of U.A . ..... for 3 years, and likely other donors'; (b) Counterpart funds have been provided and used in accordance with the relevant financing agreements, due attention to economy and efficiency, and only for the purpose for which they were provided; (c) Goods and services financed have been procured in accordance with the relevant financing agreement; (d) All necessary supporting documents, records, and accounts have been kept in respect of all program ventures [including expenditures reported via SOEs or SAs]. Clear linkages should exits between the books of account and reports presented to the contributing donors. (e) The Credit account reconciliation between the amount shown as "received by the Program from such donor" and shown as being disbursed by the Bank has been properly prepared and is presented as an annex to the PFS. This reconciliation statement should indicate the mechanism of disbursement, i.e, Special Account, Statement of Expenditures, or direct payments.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 8: Page 2 of 4 (f) The program accounts have been prepared in accordance with consistently applied International Accounting Standards and give a true and fair view of the financial situation of the program as of June 30, December 31, 1999, 2000, 2001 and of resources and expenditures for the semi-annual years ended on those dates. Program Financial Statements The Program Financial Statements should include: (a) a Statement of Source (summary of funds received, showing the World Bank, ADB other donors funds, Government Counterpart funds, and beneficiary contribution separately) and Application of Funds (summary of Expenditures shown under the main program headings and by main categories of expenditures for the current year); (b) a Balance Sheet showing Accumulated Funds of the Program, bank balances, fixed assets, inventories, other assets of the program, and liabilities, if any; and (c) notes to the financial statements presenting background information on the program, the accounting principles, details analysis and relevant explanation of the main accounts/major balances, etc. Statements of Expenditures In addition to the audit of the PFS, the auditor is required to audit all SOEs used during the year under review as the basis for the submission of withdrawal applications. The auditor should apply such tests and controls as the auditor considers necessary under the circumstances, ensuring that the existing internal control procedures for the preparation and processing of the said SOEs are sound and reliable. The auditor should examine carefully the expenditures to ensure that: i) they are genuine program expenditures and eligible with regard to the relevant financing agreement and with reference to the program documents of the donors for guidance when considered necessary; and ii) they are reasonable with respect to the planned activities included in the annual work program and budget. Where ineligible expenditures are identified as having been included in withdrawal applications and reimbursed against, there should be a schedule listing individual SOE withdrawal applications for specific reference number and amount. The total withdrawals under the SOE procedure should agree with the overall reconciliation of bank disbursements prepared by the program and described above. A separate opinion to that effect will be issued by the auditor as indicated in the introductory paragraph. Special Accounts In conjunction with the audit of the Program Financial Statement, the auditor is also required to prepare a Special Account reconciliation and audit the activities on the Special Accounts associated with the Program. The Special Account usually comprise but is not limited to:
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 8: Page 3 of 4 * deposit and replenishments received from the donors * payment substantiated by withdrawal applications * interest that may be earned from the balances and which belong to the borrower; and * the remaining balances at the end of the fiscal year. The auditor must form a separate opinion as to the degree of compliance with the Bank's procedures and the balance of the Special Account at the year-end. The audit should examine the eligibility and correctness and financial transactions during the period under review and fund balances at the end of such a period, the operation and use of the SA in accordance with the financing agreement, and the adequacy of internal controls for this type of disbursement mechanism. For the program, the Special Accounts are referred to in legal agreements between the donors and the Government of Sierra Leone. Special Accounts statements and the auditor's separate opinion thereon should accompany the Program Financial Statements. Internal Control System The auditor is required to perform an in-depth and comprehensive review of the program internal control system. Such a review would be larger in scope than what is normally required for ordinary audits. The objective of the review is to provide the auditor with sufficient understanding of the rules and procedures of the internal control system, including the existing administrative, accounting, financial, and budgetary Manual of procedures, and to determine whether the said rules and procedures are adequate, reliable, and operating correctly. In this vein, the auditor should assess with particular attention and determine whether: i) the computerized financial accounting, and reporting system in place is appropriate; ii) the accounting and financial staff within the FMPU is capable of managing the program efficiently using the computerized system. The findings and observations of the auditor should be presented in a separate report, the Management Letter, addressed along with the audit report to the borrower's representative. The Management Letter should highlight all the weaknesses in the program internal control system, assess the inherent risks associated with the internal control shortcomings, and make practical and relevant recommendations to improve the system as well as to enhance the managerial skills and capability of the accounting and financial staff. In the Management Letter, the auditor will, inter-alia: (a) give comments and observations on the accounting records, systems and controls that were examined during the course of the audit; (b) identify specific deficiencies and areas of weakness in systems and controls and make recommendation for their improvement; (c) report on the degree of compliance of each of the financial covenants on the financing agreement and give comments, if any, on internal and external matters affecting such compliance; (d) communicate matter that have come to attention during the audit which might have a significant impact on the implementation of the project; (e) bring to the borrower's attention any other matters that auditors considers pertinent.

 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 10: Page I of3 Consultancy to Design the Monitoring and Evaluation System for the Government of Sierra Leone DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE The signing of the Lome Peace Agreement in July 1999 brought a spirit of hope to the people of Sierra Leone. Government and the people now look forward to moving the country from a period of emergency to one of reconstruction and resettlement. The implementation of the long-delayed socio-economic recovery programme should assist with the consolidation of the peace and laying the foundations for sustained economic growth. To this end, the Commission eagerly looks forward to kick starting the NRRRP which was abrogated by political instability which has was predicated by civil conflict. Given the fact Government is in partnership with other stakeholders and implementing partners, it is a necessary condition that a robust but effective and flexible monitoring and evaluation system is set up that would be economy-wide, but embraces the various compartments or sub-programmes/projects of the other stakeholders and implementing partners. This system would harmonise all the other sub-systems and generate a common data- base from which the entire spectrum of assistance to the country's recovery programme can be evaluated The NCRRR and its partner agencies recognise the need for an effective and holistic monitoring and evaluation system that will provide accurate and timely information on the entire economic and social recovery programmes and sub-projects that are being implemented countrywide. This should enable the making of appropriate and timely management decisions. It is in this context that this consultancy is required OBJECTIVE Working with the Director of Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation as the National Counterpart, the consultant will assist the Commission to develop a comprehensive M & E system for the NRRP which will take into account all the sub-programmes being implemented by the various partners of the Government in the socio-economic recovery process. The system to be developed should provide senior management with an effective tool to: * Provide a bird's eye view of the entire NRRP at a glance; * Assess the administrative performance of the central and regional levels of the NCRRR;
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 10: Page 2 of 3 * Provide information on the progress and constraints affecting the implementation of programmes and sub-projects in order to be able to take appropriate and timely action; * Provide on a regular basis and on special requests a concise status and analysis of RRR activities; * Analyse the impact of programme activities as implemented by RRR partner organisations in terms of their contribution to rehabilitation, reconstruction and poverty reduction. Specifically, the consultant will: * Analyse all the donor-supported RRR programmes and projects (CRRP, CRRP/ADB, EAP, PDP, and any other) with a specific focus on extracting from these specific objectives for the programme's components, activities, inputs and outputs related to these; * Based on the programme and individual project components, develop the framework and quantitative indicators for the overall programme performance as regards to: i) overall funding of programme ii) institutional capacity of NCRRR to manage programmes; iii) individual project inputs, outputs and outcomes iv) service delivery performance including a measure for effectiveness of the ERSF and other sub-project review, approval and disbursements of funds v) ensuring an equitable balance in approved sub-projects in terms of geographical distribution, priority sectors and especially vulnerable groups such as women and ex-combatants t Examine existing and proposed reporting procedures and formats and recommend, when relevant, revisions and additions necessary for the satisfactory performance of the M&E system. * Develop a strategy for the computerisation of M&E information taking into account the existing conditions and human resource capacity;  TechnicalAnnex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 11: Page I of 13 OVERVIEW OF THE EMERGENCY RECOVERY SUPPORT FUND (REVISED AUGUST 1998) 1. Overview The Emergency Recovery Support Fund (ERSF) is a Government of Sierra Leone initiative co-ordinated by the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation (NCRRR) to help address the negative social and economic affects of more than seven years of civil war and ten months of junta rule. The Commission has been charged with the responsibility of helping rebuild the country and will do so in collaboration with key donor and implementing partner organizations. Several donor organizations, including the World Bank, the African Development Bank, and the UNDP, will support the efforts of the Commission to address the urgent needs of resettling displaced people and refugees, restoring basic social services and infrastructure in the war affected areas, reintegrating ex-combatants, and addressing the needs of peace building and reconciliation. The ERSF will also support a labor- intensive public works program designed to assist the poorest members of society in the principal urban centers. The ERSF will finance community-based projects, which address the priority needs of internally displaced persons, refugees, former combatants, and vulnerable groups in urban centers. The Fund will be used to address multi-sectoral needs; starting with more urgent food production and temporary shelter, and running through medium and longer term concerns for basic infrastructure repair and rehabilitation of productive assets. These projects will be implemented by eligible partners who include international and national NGOs, government line ministries, existing donor project units, and qualified community-based organizations. The Commission and the ERSF can only begin to support the long process of rebuilding the country; other funding and implementation strategies will be necessary to address the overall needs for reconstruction and rehabilitation. As the country moves from an emergency recovery phase to a longer- term developmental one, more strategic sectoral investment programs implemented through the respective line ministries and implementing partners will be required. As well as sharing this responsibility for helping rebuild the country with line ministries and implementing partners, the ERSF must also serve to catalyze the self-help efforts of each village. In the end, the local population must take the initiative and responsibility for rebuilding the individual lives, community infrastructure, and social ties negatively affected by the war and unrest. The Fund will rely on a decentralized bottom-up project planning, approval and monitoring process, which taps into and builds upon existing systems and structures at the regional and local levels. NGOs, line ministries and other entities will be called upon to design sub-projects in close collaboration with village, section and chiefdom authorities. Regional NCRRR staff will have primary responsibility for day-to-day management of the project review process. Regional committees will be formed and composed of two NCRRR staff members, a Ministry of Finance, Development and Economic Planning representative, the regional HACU field officer, and one representative of the implementing partners to be selected by the Inter-agency Forum. These regional Projects Committees will have the responsibility and authority to approve projects up to a maximum given level. NCRRR headquarters' staff will provide the broad policy and program-planning framework for the ERSF, monitor its implementation and co- ordinate the overall process.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment II: Page 2 of 13 The ERSF has been designed through a process of consultation, investigation, and consensus building initiated by the then Ministry of National Reconstruction, Rehabilitation and Resettlement, and others, in mid-1996. Over a ten-month period immediately preceding the coup, MNRRR staff, central and regional government authorities, national and international NGOs, and key international agencies and donors involved in the rehabilitation and recovery process were consulted on how best such a funding mechanism should work. This collaborative process culminated in two stakeholder workshops to elaborate and finalize these procedures with Ministry staff, NGO representatives, HACU and the World Bank held in November 1996 and May 1997. The workshop participants identified nine principles, which should underpin both the design and implementation of the ERSF. These are: 1. the ERSF and the National Resettlement, Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Program (NRRRP) is operating in a dynamic and changing environment-- therefore, the Fund's operation systems must be flexible and open to revision as the situation on the ground and in the provinces also changes, 2. given the fluid nature of the program environment, phasing of different aspects of the Fund, and its administrative systems, must be considered, 3. the Fund's administration should be decentralized and have a regional focus, 4. the Fund should tie into existing systems and structures; be coordinated and integrated at provincial levels, 5. the project review and monitoring process must be open and transparent, 6. the systems must operate quickly without sacrificing accountability, 7. the Fund should support productive activities, 8. the Fund should emphasize community and stakeholder participation, and 9. the administrative procedures should not adversely affect the existing relationships among NGOs, or between NGOs and the communities with which they work. The consultative process used to arrive at these procedures created a shared vision of how the ERSF should work, and a shared responsibility for its successful implementation among the Commission and its implementing partners. This spirit of partnership and collaboration should be maintained as the Fund begins operating. If the systems and procedures do not function as envisioned then it should be seen as the joint responsibility of all parties to ensure that a new system be put in place that works. Furthermore, subsequent reviews and revisions of these systems should draw upon these same collaborative mechanisms and co-operation to devise ways of better implementing the program as experience is gained. Specifically, NCRRR will conduct a detailed review of the ERSF procedures and projects six months after the fund is fully operational (expected to be October, 1998) in order to test the effectiveness of the procedures proposed herein. The review will look at, inter alia, the effectiveness of the project review process, the membership of the approval committees, the level of project approval authority at regional level, and community representation in the overall process. This document serves as both an overview of the ERSF for donors and other interested parties, and as guidelines to potential implementing partners for the preparation of project proposals for consideration by the NCRRR. The document is divided into four subsequent sections that deal with the overall objectives of the ERSF, evaluation criteria and the project selection process, administration of funds, and procedures for project monitoring. A more detailed Operational Manual has also been prepared for use by NCRRR staff in overseeing the implementation of the ERSF.

Objectives and Principles of the ERSF The objectives of the ERSF are: * To assist communities and vulnerable social groups in re-establishing their livelihood and production systems; * To help rehabilitate community level infrastructure (roads, schools, clinics, water systems, court barries, rural markets, irrigation systems) damaged during the conflict and in the poorest sections of Freetown and other urban centres, in accordance with needs and priorities as expressed by communities themselves; * To support the re-establishment of basic service provision in the fields of health, education, agriculture, etc. in areas affected by the conflict; * To provide support to local-level initiatives aimed at reconciliation and rebuilding social structures damaged during the years of the conflict; and * To strengthen the capacity of local organisations to provide effective support to longer-term processes of reconstruction and development. Projects qualifying for support under the ERSF should be developed and implemented in accordance with the following principles: 1. Enhance the opportunities for self-reliance of displaced and affected communities; 2. Strengthen local capacity to implement and manage reconstruction and development activities; 3. Promote awareness and sensitivity for gender equity and the protection of the specially disadvantaged (e.g., children, widows and the disabled) in the decision-making process; 4. Maximize grassroots participation and input in the project cycle; 5. Promote an integrated approach to resettlement and rehabilitation; and 6. Build the objectives of maintaining peace, reconciliation andforgiveness into the resettlement process. 3. Basic Eligibility Criteria To be eligible for funding under the ERSF, implementing organizations and the project must meet certain basic criteria. These criteria are sub-divided between institutional, sectoral, geographic, target group and financial, as discussed below. 3.1 Criteria for Implementing Partners For an organization to be eligible for funding under the ERSF it must meet the following organizational criteria: * be a legal entity registered in Sierra Leone and able to enter into a legally binding contract; * have a minimum of 2 years working experience (within or outside Sierra Leone) implementing the same or similar activities as those proposed to the ERSF; * have adequate infrastructure and personnel currently based in the region of proposed activity to carry out the project;
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment II: Page 4 of 13 * have adequate administrative and financial management systems and procedures in place to safe guard the use of ERSF resources; and * have no legal dispute or debts which would materially affect the institution's ability to undertake the project. 3.2 Project Types In line with the overall objectives of the National Resettlement, Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Program, the ERSF will support only those projects that address the following broad sectors and areas of activity: * Agricultural Rehabilitation: including support to basic productive activities primarily through the provision of seeds, tools and emergency food supply (using existing food pipelines) for the farming season; support to rehabilitation of tree crops, other cash crops, fishing (through the provision of equipment) and animal husbandry (through re-stocking of animals and provision of veterinary drugs); * Shelter: principally to provide temporary shelter and provide the planning framework for permanent facilities; * Rehabilitation of Community Infrastructure: to support the rehabilitation of schools, health centres, court barries, water supply, roads, rural market-places and other priorities as identified by communities; * Re-establishment of Essential Services: to provide human and material resources essential to the re-establishment of basic health and education services in collaboration with the relevant ministries; * Reintegration of Vulnerable Groups: supporting the reintegration of specific groups (e.g., widows, female head of households, ex-combatants, children affected by the war and disabled people) into communities; which may include temporary safety nets, vocational training, capital/credit, counselling/trauma healing, information, employment (e.g. labour- intensive public works), education and/or functional literacy; * Promotion of Reconciliation: for programs promoting reconciliation and conflict resolution at the community level; which may include developing conflict resolution skills, promoting reconciliation through local media, supporting youth, community and voluntary associations with the potential for promoting reconciliation; * Jobs Creation through Public Works: to establish a temporary social safety net mechanism targeting vulnerable groups of unemployed and ex-combatants living and working in urban ((Freetown and provincial capitals) and rural areas; labour-intensive works will be supported in environmental sanitation and waste disposal, road repair and maintenance, public building maintenance, reforestation, etc. * Small Enterprise Promotion and Vocational Training Schemes: designed to support development of productive skills among individual target group members and generating income and employment at community level; and * Capacity-Building: of local organisations in all of the above areas the development. 3.3 Geographic Focus The ERSF will be active throughout the regions and districts of Sierra Leone that has been affected by the war. Priority will be given to supporting populations returning to rural areas and for those areas most severely affected by the war. The Fund will also support labor-intensive public works activities that target the most vulnerable groups of unemployed in the urban and rural areas.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 11: Page 5 of 13 The ERSF will co-ordinate with other donor recovery activities (e.g., EU Resettlement and Rehabilitation Program, line ministry emergency plans, NGO initiatives, etc.) so as to avoid duplication and overlap in their areas of operation. The procedures and mechanisms for project review and approval will also support the funding mechanism of the Government's Social Action and Poverty Alleviation (SAPA) Program, which is located within NCRRR. 3.4 Target Groups To be eligible for consideration, any project proposal presented to the ERSE must target the following beneficiary groups: * internally displaced persons and refugees who left their homes and communities due to the war and/or subsequent civil strife that resulted from junta rule and its aftermath; * people in war-affected villages who never moved but are taking initiatives to re-establish themselves and their communities as well as people returning spontaneously to their villages from displaced camps, bush camps and other areas; * vulnerable groups, such as female headed households; children affected by the conflict through war trauma, being orphaned, or disrupted schooling; and disabled people, including those severely injured or traumatised by the war; e ex-combatants and their dependants; and * urban unemployed living in the poorest areas of Freetown, Makeni, Bo, and Kenema. 3.5 Financial Restrictions The following budget restrictions and financial guidelines will govern ERSF projects: * no project budget and supported activities should exceed 12 months duration, nor go beyond the 3-year mandate of the Commission; * a maximum funding limit of approximately Le.850,000,000 (US$500,000) per project will apply; * at any given time, the ERSF will not provide funding to an organisation in excess of 50% of the organisation's previous year's annual budget; * only allowable cost categories (as defined in the proposal development guidelines) will be considered for financing under the ERSF; * no counter-part funds are required of implementing partners; however, community in-kind contributions will be encouraged for community infrastructure projects (clinics, schools, etc.); * up to a maximum of 20% of the total ERSF proposed project budget will be allowed for "organisational" costs including administrative costs, overheads, general equipment which would not directly benefit the community, etc.; and * purchase of large assets such as institutional infrastructure, vehicles, etc. will be discouraged, and the disposition of any vehicles upon project completion will be the subject of negotiation between NCRRR and the implementing partner. 4. Technical Evaluation Criteria Once a project and organization are shown to meet the basic eligibility criteria listed above, projects submitted to the ERSF will be reviewed and evaluated based on two sets of technical criteria, general and specific.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 11: Page 6 of l3 4.1 General Criteria General criteria will be applied to each project proposal by the ERSF secretariat staff (see sections 5.1 and 5.2) in assessing overall project design and fundability. This assessment would look at institutional, financial, social and environmental criteria, project coherence, and sustainability. These categories of criteria are described in more detail below. Institutional criteria; including number and types of personnel, available infrastructure and physical resources to carry out project, financial management and administrative systems, years and types of experience, project value relative to overall organizational finances, etc. Project coherence; including relation between identified problems, causes and proposed solutions, the clarity and specificity of project objectives and links to proposed project activities, feasibility of achieving the proposed end results, completeness and reasonability of the monitoring plan, and the innovativeness or creativity of the project design. Financial criteria; including a clear relation between project activities and budget items, reasonableness of proposed inputs and unit costs, inputs conform with standard specifications and applicable market rates, budget form and substance in agreement with guidelines (no unacceptable expenditure categories, adequate information, etc.), and the relative level of "direct" and "indirect" costs. Sustainability criteria; including level and substance of community participation in project planning and implementation, level of local knowledge or skills required for implementation, level of local labor and/or materials in project, level of operation or maintenance costs once project is complete, viability of maintenance plan, impact on disposable time of women, income generating potential of project, and effect project has on environment and natural resources. Social criteria; including understanding of ethnic characteristics of community and region, impact on vulnerable groups, and potential conflicts or obstacles between different groups or institutions within community. Environmental criteria; including identification and mitigation of potential environmental impacts of the proposed projects, in particular issues related to health and sanitation, natural resource exploitation and pesticide use. This review will be carried out by ERSF/NCRRR staff in the offices and at the proposed sites of the implementing partners. Clearly, the larger, more complex and more costly the project, the more detailed and thorough the general technical review will be. In particular, the regional and district level staff of NCRRR should assess the extent to which the project reflects the priorities of the community in which the project will be implemented. 4.2 Specific Technical Criteria Suitable line ministries and technical sub-committees (as appropriate) in each region will conduct specific technical evaluations of each proposal. It will be the responsibility of these groups to apply appropriate technical criteria to the project review; such criteria will vary depending on the project type (i.e., agriculture, infrastructure, basic services, or enterprise development). In general, however, these sub- committees or task forces would look at the following areas in making a technical assessment of the project:

 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 12: Page I of 2 TERMS OF REFERENCE Assessment of the Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project Pilot Phase Background The Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project (CRRP) and the related Emergency Recovery Support Fund (ERSF), and Training and Employment Program (TEP) are Government of Sierra Leone initiatives co-ordinated by the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement and Rehabilitation (NCRRR) and the National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (NCDDR) to help address the negative social and economic affects of more than seven years of civil war and ten months of junta rule. The Commission and Committee have been charged with the responsibility of helping rebuild the country and will do so in collaboration with key donor and implementing partner organisations. Several donor organisations, including the World Bank, the African Development Bank, and the UNDP, support the efforts of these Government institutions to address the urgent needs of resettling displaced people and refugees, restoring basic social services and infrastructure in the war affected areas, reintegrating ex-combatants, and addressing the needs of peace building and reconciliation. The CRRP also supports labour-intensive public works activities designed to assist the most vulnerable members of society. The CRRP finances community based sub-projects which address the priority needs of internally displaced persons, refugees, former combatants, and other vulnerable groups in both rural and urban areas throughout the country. These sub-projects address multi-sectoral needs; starting with more urgent food production and temporary shelter, and running through medium and longer term concerns for basic infrastructure repair and rehabilitation of productive assets. The sub-projects are implemented by eligible partners which include international and national NGOs, government line ministries, existing donor project units, and qualified community based organisations. As the financial resources available through CRRP can only begin to support the long process of rebuilding the country; the Project also looks to catalysing the self-help efforts of each village and community. The Project and the ERSF have been designed through a process of consultation, investigation, and consensus-building initiated by the earlier Ministry of National Reconstruction, Rehabilitation and Resettlement in mid-1996. The ERSF relies on a decentralised bottom-up project planning, approval and monitoring process which taps into and builds upon existing systems and structures at the regional and local levels. NGOs, line ministries and other entities develop project proposals in close collaboration with village, section and chiefdom authorities. Regional NCRRR staff have primary responsibility for day-to-day management of the project review process. Regional inter-agency committees have been formed and given the responsibility to approve projects up to a maximum given level. NCRRR headquarters' staff provide the broad policy and programme planning framework for the ERSF, monitor its implementation and co-ordinate the overall process. In anticipation of an IDA credit worth more than US$20 million, the World Bank is supporting NCRRR and the ERSF to carry out pilot activities during latter 1998 and early 1999. More than 20 projects worth almost US$1 million have been reviewed and approved, and have begun implementation under the Bank's Project Preparation Facility. In light of the innovative nature of the Fund, and the high degree of inter-agency collaboration and co-operation called for in it implementation, the Government and the World Bank have decided that a detailed review of the ERSF is required before larger-scale implementation begins. These terms of reference are for that review.
