 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 13: Page I of 4 Social Safety Net Component of the CRRP It has been agreed with Government that as part of the Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project (CRRP) a social safety net component would be implemented that would focus on labor-intensive public works programs. The target beneficiaries of this temporary safety net would be ex-combatants, unemployed urban youth, and members of recently returned rural communities, and other traditional vulnerable groups such as female-headed households, etc. The safety net component will be operational for the same three-year period that the CRRP will be effective. After careful consideration of worldwide experiences with social safety net schemes, and consultations with likely implementing partners and Government authorities responsible for relevant aspects of such an intervention, the following observations and recommendations are made. Project Design and Selection Criteria 1. Wage rate is the critical determinant of targeting as well as distribution of benefits in favor of poor participants. In general, a wage that is close to or slightly below the prevailing market wage for unskilled labor is most likely to encourage self-selection of the poor into the program, to maximize the amount of temporary employment created under the program. Based on an assessment of current market practices, related works programs managed by the Sierra Leonean Works Authority, and non- governmental organizations' food-for-work activities, the prevailing daily rate is approximately Le.1,500. This finding is roughly consistent with earlier findings of World Bank missions. Therefore, it is recommended that the wage rate for the CRRP's social safety net component not exceed this level. 2. Share of wages to total project cost. As the first objective of this component is to provide for temporary employment opportunities for the identified vulnerable groups, the component should strive to maximize the labor content of funded projects. Based on both reviews of proposed projects, and experience in similar countries, the labor component of a projectI should represent approximately 50% of the total cost. Therefore, a target range of 40 to 70 percent should be recommended for the CRRP, depending on the type and location of a project. Projects with labor costs above this range would not ensure adequate quality of the completed projects, and below this range would not meet the objective of the program. 3. Geographic targeting. In order to make it easiest for the identified vulnerable groups to participate in the component, and therefore reduce transaction costs, it is recommended that proposed activities target those areas where there is general agreement that the concentration of poverty is greatest. For instance, in Freetown such areas include Goderich, Congo Town/Banana Water areas, Dworzak Farm, Redpump, Kroobay, OdokokolMountain Court, Mabella, Ginger Hall, and many pockets in Kissy and Wellington. In addition, those rural communities that have recently returned home (i.e., the majority of the population having arrived within the previous 12 months) should be targeted. 4. Other design features. Project designs should include other features that facilitate broad participation; for example, piece-rate or task-based payment, flexible timing of participation (where possible), provision of day care arrangements, and timing not to conflict with other demands such as planting season, or the school year for youths. Labor costs directed at the target group or groups; i.e., excluding supervisory and/or management personnel costs
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 13: Page 2 of 4 Project Identification and Development While the CRRP wishes to target those vulnerable groups identified for the social safety net component of the Project, the overall implementation strategy of the CRRP is to use a community-based demand driven project identification and development process. This same strategy is advisable for the social safety net component for consistency sake and also to encourage that the social and/or economic infrastructure created, rehabilitated or maintained through the public works activity is considered a priority by the community that will ultimately use it. Therefore, it is expected that NGOs, line ministries, or public authorities (such as SLRA) will prepare project proposals through consultation with relevant communities and/or identified vulnerable groups. By doing so, not only will the priorities of the community be better expressed in the project design, but the ownership of the end-product greater-- thus encouraging on-going community maintenance of the asset. Project proposals must demonstrate that the requisite technical input, standards and/or norms have been taken into consideration and that appropriate technical supervision will be available for project implementation. For instance, road rehabilitation or maintenance activities should reflect the SLRA norms and should cater for adequate monitoring, works rehabilitation proposals should have standard drawings and bills of quantities attached (if appropriate), works involving sanitation, agriculture or reforestation should indicate how the relevant line ministries (health and agriculture) have been consulted in project design and will be involved in implementation. Project Review and Selection It is recommended that the proposed ERSF project review and approval procedures overseen by NCRRR be used for the social safety net component of the CRRP. The same staff and organizational structures are capable of handling these types of projects, and the inter-agency review process will help guarantee both technical suitability of projects and coordination with other similar activities (such as food for work or food for agriculture). Specific technical criteria (indicated below) should be incorporated into the ERSF Operational Manual and be used in reviewing and assessing these types of public works projects. Technical review and inter-agency approval structures have been established to assess and select community based projects that are adequately suited to the task of reviewing labor-intensive works projects. The recent revisions to the institutional structure of NCRRR that include adding a Western Area office and seeking civil engineers for district level posts, will facilitate the inclusion of public works project proposals in the review process. As with the ERSF, NCRRR is the coordinating institution and financing channel for project activities; the actual implementing agencies will be the partner organizations to the ERSF; namely NGOs, line ministries, and public authorities. Specific Review Criteria * The component's priority should be to create temporary employment among the most vulnerable, while at the same time optimizing the social, economic and/or physical infrastructure of the community and, if possible, be oriented toward further job creation and/or income generation. * Project wage rate should not exceed the prevailing market wage for unskilled labor. At present, the wage rate varies, depending on location. The average daily wage rate for unskilled labor is approximately Le 1,500. The monthly wage for unskilled labor varies, between Le 35,000 and Le 45,000 (for 25 working days). * The total wage component for unskilled labor of the public works project should be equal to or exceed 50 percent of the total project cost, on average.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 13: Page 3 of 4 Depending on the type of public works and the location, wages could be paid in both cash and in- kind (i.e., food), however, the total value should not exceed a daily wage rate of Le.1, 500 as discussed above. Discussions between SLRA and NGOs, for instance, suggest that for the implementation of all food-aid projects, 30% of the labor cost shall be paid in food and 70% in cash. * The project encourages to create linkages between the proposed public works schemes and the productivity with which the works are carried out, through incorporating a piece-rate or task- based payment system for laborers. (SLRA's Feeder Roads Department, for instance, has established wage rates per man-day for 18 different road rehabilitation activities). * Proposed public works projects need to be consistent with existing labor laws. * Proposed public works projects need to be technically feasible and proposals must demonstrate that appropriate technical norms and design standards will be adhered to. * Targeted communities should participate in project design and the services or works to be delivered should respond to the needs of these groups. * Timing and design of services/works should, to the extent possible, encourage broadest participation and reduce opportunity costs of participation through seasonal timing (i.e., not during the planting or harvesting seasons) and flexible working arrangements (such as piece meal work). * The number of laborers at any one-job site should range between 50 and 75, and should not exceed 100. * During the pilot phase of the ERSF, it is not recommended that any one public works project exceed $150,000 in value. * The implementing partners proposing the public works projects need to ensure a reliable and regular flow of funds for the payment of workers and put in place a financial management system that promotes the expedient implementation of the works. * To the extent possible, proposed public works programs should be targeting communities where there is general agreement that the concentration of poverty is greatest. In the initial phase of the project, the identification of the poor will be based on geographic targeting. Priority will be given to pockets of poor in urban areas and recently returned communities in rural areas. The needs of particular vulnerable groups, such as ex-combatants, unemployed youth or female-headed households, will be addressed through these broader geographically targeted programs. Financing Modalities The same financing procedures proposed for the overall ERSF should also apply to the social safety net component of the CRRP. Namely, once a contract with an implementing partner is authorized by NCRRR, the Financial Management and Procurement Unit will manage all financial disbursements to the organization. The FMPU will be established as an autonomous unit reporting to NCRRR but which will operate independently from normnal fund disbursement procedures of the public sector. Financial staff of NCRRR at regional levels and in the Western Area will have responsibility for reviewing monthly financial reports from implementing partners. It will be the responsibility of the implementing agencies to guarantee timely disbursement of wages to laborers.
 Technical Annex Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Sierra Leone Attachment 13: Page 4 of 4 Implementation Mechanisms The mission met with various Government agencies and NGO organizations and was able to confirm the conclusion of previous World Bank missions that considerable capacity exists in Sierra Leone, both in the private sector and in the local and international NGO community, to carry out labor-intensive public works programs. Since a recent CRRP mission, in May'98, several public works activities have been initiated or are being prepared. WFP implementing partners alone will employ 78,000 people for food- for-agriculture activities over a five-month period from May to September of the current year. NGOs like CARE, CRS, and World Vision have also been implementing food-for-a.griculture programs during the ongoing rainy season and are preparing food-for-work programs for the upcoming dry season. Certain organizations are also contemplating cash-for-work programs. During recent discussions between the government (SLRA) and some of its implementing partners (NGOs), agreement was reached that for the implementation of all food-aid projects, 30% of the labor cost shall be paid in food and 70% in cash. In addition, the Government is encouraging linkages between the proposed public works schemes and the productivity with which the works are carried out. In particular, through incorporating a piece-rate or task-based payment system for laborers. SLRA's Feeder Roads Department, for instance, has established piece rates per man-day for 18 different road rehabilitation activities. To improve implementation capacity in Moyamba, Bonthe and Pujehan districts, SLRA field staff and several small-scale contractors are currently involved in refresher courses and skills upgrading training on emergency spot improvement of feeder roads and bridges. The Ministry of Youth has prepared several public works proposals for urban youth, and Civil Development Units have continued to mobilize urban youth to do voluntary work such as garbage cleaning. These developments indicate a growing capacity to plan and implement public works programs in both urban as well as rural Sierra Leone. The mission is of the opinion that for the implementation of its Social Safety Net component, the CRRP can largely rely on this increasing capacity. Monitoring and Evaluation The established procedures and mechanisms in place for monitoring the ERSF will be used to monitor the labor-intensive works activities. Specifically, district level staff (supervisors and community development officers) and the Western Area manager and project officer will monitor specific indicators of progress. These will include timely payment of wages, level of employment created (man-days), timely completion of works, and quality of works. In assessing the latter two aspects of the physical works carried out, NCRRR staff will seek the assistance of the Government line ministries and public authorities as necessary.

doc.repnme: Sierra Leone - Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The Community Reintegration and Rehabilitation Project aims to contribute to increased security, social stability, and economic revival by helping former combatants and the population and communities affected by the conflict return to normal, productive lives. The number of potential beneficiaries is estimated to reach 1.5 million, close to one third of the population. The project is expected to have a significant impact on reducing war-induced poverty throughout Sierra Leone, particularly by helping reinvigorate the local economy. The project will entail two components: 1) Emergency Recovery Support Fund, and related institutional support to the National Commission for Reconstruction, Resettlement, and Rehabilitation and partners will facilitate the social and economic recovery of communities and the restoration of basic social and economic services through demand-driven, community-oriented projects that target individuals, groups and the community affected by the conflict. 2) Training and Employment Program, and related institutional support to the National Committee on Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration will support the social and economic reintegration of former combatants through targeted counseling, training, and employment creation efforts.
